H.P.R.
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:abbreviation
Sense Number:
Definition:homestead pre-emptive right
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1981 
Source: Station Years
Author: CRAWFORD
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: Although many runholders came to regard the land they leased as their own, their occupancy was intended to be only a temporary using of waste land until it was required for closer settlement.  Anyone - the runholder included - could buy the freehold of all or any part of a run at any time to establish a farm. However, some protection for runholders was essential, for they could not be expected to improve their runs if the land and improvements were in danger of being freeholdedwithout warning by an outside buyer. Runholders were able to register with the Provincial Council improvements such as buildings, plantations, fencing, and yards, for which they were granted [246] an improvement pre-emptive right (I.P.R.) covering fifty acres of land surrounding the improvement. A homestead pre-emptive right (H.P.R.), which afforded protection for 250 acres, could also be registered. ... One H.P.R. could be taken out for each property and it was only businesslike that each runholder should use this right to secure 250 acres around his homestead against purchase by an outsider. An H.P.R. was initially intended to cover the owner's or manager's home, but, in the case of runs of over 5,000 acres, could be extended to cover an outstation.
Notes: [ca1878]

Date: 4/5/1907 
Source: NZ Truth
Author: 
Vol / Page: 98/2/3
Edition: 
Quote: The term `hack' as understood in this country is not at all to be conflicted with the same term as applied elsewhere to horse racing under that category. A hack in New Zealand is a horse that has not won a certain amount of moneys [sic], and so it is quite possible for the Derby favorite of the year, or the New Zealand Cup favorite to be a hack.
Notes:

Habitual Criminal

Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1945 
Source: In Prison
Author: BURTON
Vol / Page: 133
Edition: 
Quote: This is an indeterminate sentence, and can only be given to a man who has been declared an Habitual Criminal. ... Unless the `Act' is lifted from him by a judge of the Supreme Court it willcontinue in force for the rest of his life. Among convicts this particular sentence is is known as the `dog collar' for obvious reasons.
Notes: 

Date: 0/11/1950 
Source: Here & Now
Author: 
Vol / Page: 14
Edition: 
Quote: GLOSSARY OF TECHNICAL TERMS: A boobhead is a prisoner; a screw is a warder; a topper is a toady or an informer. The Act or the Collar - The Habitual Criminals Act, under which persons declared habitual criminals can have their sentences increased by the Prisons Board for offences against prison discipline during their incarceration.
Notes: (Ian Hamilton `NZd's Last Flogging')

Date: 0/0/1980 
Source: While We Have Prisons
Author: MacKENZIE
Vol / Page: 9
Edition: 
Quote: In 1953 I made a study ... of New Zealand's habitual criminals. These 520 people ... had received the accolade of New Zealand criminality ... In prison language they had beengiven the `collar', the `key', the Kathleen Mavourneen sentence - `It may be for years and it may be for ever'. ... The unfortunate recipients of the new title `Habitual Criminal' would serve a head sentence of Hard Labour to be followed by an unspecified period of imprisonment which could last until death.
Notes:

haddock
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:In early use applied to NZ fishes thought to resemble northern haddock, esp. australis.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1840 
Source: Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author: POLACK
Vol / Page: 1/202 fn
Edition: 
Quote: Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called <i>para</i>[as-acute] <i> paraua</i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale,<i> mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale,  <i> tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark,  <i> mango</i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes. 
Notes:

Date: 0/6/1946 
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author: 
Vol / Page: 55/148
Edition: 
Quote: haeremai, cry of welcome; really two words - haere, come; mai, this way - come along! Haereatu, go away! Be off! atu, away from the speaker. [OEDS 1933] <i>Ibid.</I> 150  haeremai, as this is included in the Dictionary, haerera also should be included, the former being the response to the latter.  
Notes: (J.C.Andersen)

Date: 5/8/1820 
Source: Journal
Author: CRUISE
Vol / Page: 134
Edition: 1957
Quote: ...the women on either side waving their mats, and shouting Heromai (Come hither) to each other.  ibid. 214 [Notes] March 29th. Heromai, or `Come hither', is the salutation of peace and friendship. Where this word is not pronounced on the approach of the stranger the feelings of the people are not favourable towards him.
Notes:

Edition: 
Quote: Had we been Maoris of course we should there and then have also squatted down and rubbed noses. Hereafter I will explain why at such meetings the natives do not jump up and say how glad they are to see you, but welcome you in woe-begone `Haere mai's', squatting down and rubbing the lugubrious nose until the spectacle is anything but pleasant to look at. <i>Ibid.</i>4/4/267 The `haeremais' and `tautemais' - `come' - `come to my arms' of some blanketed figures standing near some huts seemed to exercise the most uncontrollable influence over my friends, ...

haere ra
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:exclamation
Sense Number:
Definition:Farewell (to one departing) [Maori haere r&amacr.(phs popularised as the title of a well-known Maori song) (Williams: haere v. come; go, depart: ra av. there, yonder; or a particle denoting distance from the speaker), said to a person leaving, goodbye, farewell. 
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1881 
Source: Poenamo
Author: CAMPBELL
Vol / Page: 33
Edition: 
Quote: You can see a good many bundles of blankets and black top-knots scattered over the beach, all immovable. That is the native fashion of  bidding goodbye, ... [34] But meanwhile we must `haere' along or we shall never get clear of Herekino.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1938 
Source: Nor the Years Condemn
Author: HYDE
Vol / Page: 169
Edition: 
Quote: `Haere ra, I'm going to Napier to get my divorce.' You never hear such a korero. They don't like a divorce.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1946 
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author: 
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: haeremai, as this is included in the Dictionary,haerera also should be included, the former being the response to the latter.  <I>Ibid.</i> 55/151 haerera,term of farewell, said by the one who stays to the one who goes: ra, an indefinite `yonder.' The reply by the departer is: e noho (lit. sit still), or hei konei ra (for you this place).<I>Ibid.</I> 151 haerera, term of farewell, said by the one who stays to the one who goes: ra, an indefinite `yonder.' The reply by the departer is: e noho (lit. sit still), or hei konei ra (for you this place). 
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date: 0/0/1946 
Source: Where the People Sing
Author: ZIMMERMAN
Vol / Page: 42
Edition: 
Quote: ... the crowd came with me, and instead of saying goodby or cheer-o, they said  Haere ra' and I liked them for it, for it means, `Go, then.'
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1947 
Source: Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.
Author: 
Vol / Page: 173
Edition: 
Quote: haere ra: farewell.

Date: 0/0/1947 
Source: Native Animals of NZ
Author: POWELL
Vol / Page: 60
Edition: 
Quote: HAG FISH (<i>Heptatretus cirrhatus</i> ). This grows to about 2 feet in length, ... even more revolting than the lamprey, to which it is closely allied. Parts of the Otago trawling grounds are termed `hospitals' by fishermen on account of the large number of wounded fish which have received the attention of the voracious hag-fish.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1956 
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide

Date: 3/12/1987 
Source: Personal Communication
Author: DAVID NORTON
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: A haggle is a bet between the players on a round of golf, part of the money allocated to the winner(s) of the first nine holes, part to the second nine (this amount may be doubled by the losers of the first nine), and part to the overall winner(s). Currently on Karori Golf Course: 50c, 50c, $1. Sometimes money is played for on each hole, but I dont think this is part of a haggle. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/2/1988 
Source: Personal Communication
Author: M.J. ORSMAN
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: Haggle is used on Judgeford Golf Course (Pauatahanui) for playing for a small prize which all concerned share in but which losing team pays for - the whole process is called a haggle. `Are we going to have a wee haggle on the match.'

Vol / Page: 130
Edition: 1961
Quote: Tekoke and most of the natives of the settlement  had left to attend a Hahunga at Taeamai. ... [131 May 30] ... two messengers arrived from Waimate ...  to request our attendance at the Ha'hunga ... <i>Ibid.</i> 244 The Chiefs Hiamoe and Pukututu came from the Kauakaua to request some of us to go up to attend the  Hahunga there, the feast which takes place at theremoval of the bones of the dead. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1835 
Source: New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author: YATE
Vol / Page: 137
Edition: 
Quote: Hahunga, a grand annual feast ... No further notice is taken of the deceased till the Hahunga, a grand annual feast; when the [138] bones of all belonging to several united tribes are taken down, and removed to their last resting-place, in or near the sacred grove. 
Notes: (Griffiths Collection)

Date: 0/0/1856

Author: SHORTLAND
Vol / Page: 147
Edition: 
Quote: A very curious ceremony, called hahunga, takes place when the skulls of the dead are exhibited to their living relations before being finally deposited in the secret family vault.

Both vowels must be short ...' -

haka
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:In a debased form, often with meaningless Maori-looking words, and, esp. in Otago, English words and cries, a school or team form of noisy encouragement, or rally; often called `the school haka'.

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1946 
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author: 
Vol / Page: 55/148-149
Edition: 
Quote: haka, general term for a posture-dance; dance with song and action: usually supposed to mean awar-dance; but the real earth-shaking and nerve-shattering war-dance is peruperu, with its savage gesturing, eye-glaring, and cries demoniac, the savagest-looking of which may be in pure fun andintended as a hearty welcome. Both vowels must be short; h&amacr.ka and hak&amacr. differ altogether in meaning: there is no word h&amacr.k&amacr..  
Notes: Andersen Maori Words in English

Date: 0/0/1946 
Source: Some Modern Maoris
Author: BEAGLEHOLE

Author: CRUISE
Vol / Page: 83
Edition: 1957
Quote: One of the gentlemen ... was present at the shackerie, or harvest home (if it may be so called), of Shungie's people. It was celebrated in a wood, where a square space had been cleared of trees, in the centre of which three very tall posts, driven into the ground in the form of a triangle, supported an immense pile of baskets of koomeras.

Date: 0/0/1859 
Source: Story of New Zealand, The
Author: THOMSON
Vol / Page: 1/189
Edition: 
Quote: The New Zealanders had another feast, called the hakari, very different from the hahunga. The hakari was a banquet given by nations to each other, ... Previously to the arrival of the guests the food was piled either on the ground or on wooden scaffolds. Such erections were sqare pyramidal towers having an elevation of fifty feet, or ranges of six feet high, extending from half a mile to two miles. There were several compartments in these receptacles for food; each being filled up with sweet potatoes, taros, maize, fern root, potted birds, dried fish, karaka berries, ... 
Notes: 

Date: 17/4/1863 
Source: Richmond-Atkinson Papers
Author: 
Vol / Page: 2/34
Edition: 1960
Quote: In afn. ... rode down to Mangaone ...[sic] where there was said to be a great hakari (feast) going on, but it had not begun... In afn. [sic] caught my poney [sic] & rode down to Mangaone ... where there was said to be a great hakari (feast) going on ... 
Notes: (A.S. Atkinson)

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1985 
Source: Towards Taha Maori
Author: HOWE
Vol / Page: 19
Edition: 
Quote: Hakari - this word referrred to the foodstand on which were displayed huge and varied amounts of food that a group was prepared to give its visitors, in order to maintain and increase their prestige or `mana'. (q.v.) The host group would make large personal sacrifices in order to feed visitors, and such sacrifice increased the sense of sharing both among hosts and between hosts and guests. Hakari now refers to the feast itself.
Notes: 1985 Howe Towards `Taha Maori' in English (NZATE) 19 

Date: 0/0/1986 
Source: NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary
Author: 
Vol / Page: 338
Edition: 
Quote: hakari n. Maori feast after a ceremonial occasion. [M]

Quote: Another matter touching on the recurring annoyance of vernacular names is that up till 1891 <i>Lotella rhacinus</i> was universally accepted as the hake: then, in 1912, Waite, for no apparent reason, transfers this name to <i>Merluccius gayi</i>, although he admits that the records ofthese fish were hopelessly mixed on the expedition. ...

Quote:  Hake = <i>Lotella rhacinus</i>. <i>Ibid.</i> 210  In report from Cape Maria van Diemen, where the terms `blue-fish' and `rock-cod' (<i>Parapercis</i>) are used together , I suspect that the former were specimens of <i>Physiculus rhacinus</i>, and this would extend the range a little.
Notes: G. M . Thomson

Date: 0/0/1912 
Source: Records of the Canterbury Museum
Author: 
Vol / Page: 1(2):182
Edition: 
Quote: This is where the confusion starts. He records <i>Merluccius gayi</i> (Guichenot)-syn. for <i>Merlus gayi</i> (Guich.) and <i>Gadus australis</i> (Hutton) - as the `hake,' and makes no independent record for <i>Physiculus rhacinus</i>, but admits that the records of the two fishes were in a state of hopeless confusion, thus tacitly admitting that specimens of both were recorded under the same name. LITERATURE WITH A SUMMARY OF THE DATA IN EACH CASE.
Notes: E. R. Waite

Date: 0/0/1840 
Source: Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author: POLACK
Vol / Page: 1/202
Edition: 
Quote:  fn Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales,called <i>para </i>[as-acute] <i>paraua </i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale,  <i>mungu nui </i> (black physeter); right whale,  <i>tohora </i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark,  <i>mango </i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

Quote: HAKE or WHITING <i>Merluccius australis</i> (Hutton) Hake is [166] known in Christchurch, and by some in Otago, as Whiting, but it is not a true Whiting. In Napier, Wellington and Marlborough the Southern Kingfish (<i>Rexea solandri</i>) is caught and sold as Hake.

Date: 0/0/1970 
Source: Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author: SORENSON
Vol / Page: 28
Edition: 
Quote: HAKE (a) Scientific name: <i>Merluccius australis</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Hake. (c) Other common names: Whiting; English Hake. (d) Principal localities where taken: Taken only rarely nowdays off Wellington in deep water; ... Whatever the position was years ago it is a fact that this fish is rare today. The position is further complicated by the almost indiscriminate use of the name hake, by fishermen, [for] other species of fish. ... The name Hake shold not be applied to either Southern kingfish or the Whiptail although there can be little, if any, objection to the commercial name of Blue Hake for the latter species.

Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 410

Date: 0/0/1956 
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 315
Edition: 2nd ed.
Quote: SOUTHERN KINGFISH or HAKE (TIKATI) <i>Rexea solandri</i> (Cuv. and Val.) .../ This fish is known as Hake in Auckland. In New South Wales it is often caught by trawlers in one hundred and fifty fathoms and is known as King Barracouta. It is a favoured food fish. In Tasmania it is referred to as Tasmanian Kingfish. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1957 
Source: Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
Author: PARROTT
Vol / Page: 43
Edition: 
Quote: There is much confusion in the common names applied to New Zealand fishes, and the application of the name `Hake' to several distinct species of our fishes, is a good example of that confusion. In Blenheim, Nelson, Picton and Wellington, a very  different fish, scientifically known as <i>Rexea solandri</i>, and closely related to the Barracouta, with obviously no affinities to the Cod family, is called `Hake' or `Southern Kingfish'. The name Hake applied to this fish is entirely wrong, as it belongs to the Snake Mackerel family, the <i>Gempylidae. </i><i>Ibid.</i> 154 SOUTHERN KINGFISH <i>Rexea solandri</i> (Cuv. & Val.) ... The Southern Kingfish is closely related to the Barracouta, and is known in the North Island as the `hake' but this name is more accurately applied to a very different fish, <i>Merlangius australis</i>, which belongs to the true Cod family. <I>Ibid.</i> 155 [Southern Kingfish, <i>Rexea Solandri</i>] is found also in southern Australian waters. In Sydney it is sold as `hake'. It is also known as `Hake' in Auckland and sometimes sold as `lemon-fish'. <i>Ibid.</i> 170 Southern Kingfish Rexea solandri Hake 
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1981 
Source: Fisherman's Bible
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 30
Edition: 
Quote: HAKE: See Southern Kingfish <i>Ibid.</i> 200 SOUTHERN KINGFISH <i>Jordanidia solandri</i>. This is the King Barracouta of Australia and the so-called Hake of more southern New Zealand waters. <i>Ibid.</i> 201 [The Southern Kingfish is] Called Hake in southern fish shops but bears no resemblance to the traditional English Hake which is far less oily. Tasmanian kingfish,  barraconda and `tikati' (Maori) are other names. <i>Ibid.</i> 141 Another so-called Kingfish occurs in southern New Zealand  waters but this is no relative of <i>Seriola Grandis</i>. He is the Silver Kingfish, who is sometimes called Hake and known in Australia as Gemfish.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1982 
Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Vol / Page: 75
Edition: 
Quote: Hake is a slender, silvery-grey fish found mainly in southern coastal waters, although it is now  not as plentiful as it used to be.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1986 
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: PAUL
Vol / Page: 121
Edition: 
Quote: Gemfish <i>Rexea solandri</i> ... Also occurs off southern Australia, as well as Japan. New Zealand names include silver or southern kingfish and hake (which is now easily confused with the true hake). The name gemfish, conveying family relationship as well as irridescence, is more appropriate.

Quote: Besides these there were many species which tho they did not at all resemble any fish that I at least have before [7] seen, our seamen contrivd to give names to, so that hakes [fn1], breams [2], Cole fish [3] &c. were appellations familiar with us, and I must say that those who bear these names in England need not be ashamed of their nam[e]sakes in this countrey. Date: 0/0/1956 
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide

Vol / Page: 172
Edition: 2nd
Quote: ROCK COD or SOUTHERN HAKE <i>Lotella rhacinus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) Up to 1891 this fish was universally known to scientists and fishermen  as Hake, then for some unknown reason E. R. Waite (<i>Records of the Canterbury Museum</i>, Vol. 1, No. 3) transferred the name Hake to <i>Merluccius gayi</i>, with Whiting as a second alternative common name. ... The most common name among Otago fishermen was Rock Cod, because this fish favours a rocky habitat.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1966 
Source: Sea Anglers' Guide
Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND
Vol / Page: 210
Edition: 
Quote: [ROCK COD] ROCK COD ... <i>Other names: Lotella rhacinus</i>; Cloudy Bay cod, southern hake.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1966 
Source: Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author: McLINTOCK
Vol / Page: 1/373
Edition: 
Quote: The Cloudy Bay cod (<i>Lotella rhacinus</i>), also known as rock cod and southern hake, is rather more brown and lacks the dark blotch by the pectoral fin. <i>Ibid.</i> 1/898 HAKE is a name applied to several quite different marine fish in  different parts of the country. The whiting or haddock, <i>Merluccius  australis</i>, is a true hake, very similar to the North Sea species; it is, actually, often called English hake. It occurs in fairly deep  water south of Cook Strait. The southern kingfish, <i>Jordanidia  solandri</i>, is also known as hake: it is closely related and similar to the barracouta, and found throughout New Zealand. The Cloudy Bay cod, <i>Lotella rhacinus</i>, is sometimes known as southern hake.(see also Kingfish.) 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1981 
Source: Fisherman's Bible
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 38
Edition: 
Quote: [ROCK COD] ... Known also as Cloudy Bay Cod in some areas and Southern Hake in others. Known in Australia as a Beardie, because of its barbel presumably.

Vol / Page: 308
Edition: 
Quote: Extinct birds ... Laughing Owl <i>Sceloglaux albifacies</i> (GRAY, 1844) OTHER NAMES: Whekau, hakoke (North Island),rock owl. The `doleful shrieks' of the laughing owl, which varied seasonally, were heard incessantly on rainy nights. Apparently it was easily kept in captivity, and reports say that it cooeyed in the evening, yelped like a young dog and mewed and chuckled. ... The most recent record of sighting was at Manapouri in 1950 ...

hakuwai
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:A  Maori legendary bird, said to be heard at night but never seen. (Suggested originals include frigate bird, Haast's eagle; the most probable being Miskelly below, i.e. NZ snipe in display flights.)  See also hokioi.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 11/9/1912 
Source: Otago Witness
Author: 
Vol / Page: 76
Edition: 
Quote: Many legends are associated with themythical bird "hokioi"... In the Southand in some parts of the North Island itis identical, apparently, with the"hakuwai" which has seven joints in itswing, lives in the sky, and presagestrouble... "Its cry was Hokioi! Hokioi!Hu!" The last word represented thewhizzing sound made by the bird inflight.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1964 
Source: Little World of Stewart island
Author: DEMPSEY
Vol / Page: 61
Edition: 
Quote: The Mysterious Ha-ka-wai Bird [heading] No-one has ever seen it, no-one knows what it is like.Mutton-birders who have heard the strange sound of its passing over the islands at night speak of the ha-ka-wai bird. A swish of wings close overhead, a sound like the rattle of chains when a boat lets the anchor down, again the sound of wingbeats and the cry floating earthward from the heavens,  Ha-ka-wai! Ha-ka-wai! in a drawn-out singsong with accent on the first and last syllables.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1906 
Source: TrNZI
Author: 
Vol / Page: 38/340
Edition: 
Quote: A strange bird in Maori eyes is the hakuai of the off-shore islands in the far south. ... Whole families go mutton-birding ... At night the fowlers gather round their camp-fires, and old songs are sung ... and ghost-stories retold. And in the darkness sometimes they hear the ghost-bird screaming its `Haku-ai, haku-ai, Ooh!' and then a hair-raising swoosh of great wings ... This bird, called the `hakuai' from its call, is spoken of as a spirit. ... The mystery of the  hakuai may be dispelled by assuming it to be ... the  frigate-bird (Fregata aquila). 
Notes: 

Date: 0/8/2000 
Source: NZWords
Author: 
Vol / Page: No. 4: 5
Edition: 
Quote: The Maori word <i>hakuwai</i> (or <i>hakawai</i> or <i>hakuai</i>, or any of at least five other variant spellings, including the European <i>harkowhy</i>) was defined by Williams in his <i>Maori Dictionary</i> as 'an extinct bird heard at night'.

Quote: The present colloquial or slang use of dollar, usually in  half a dollar, `half a crown' in New Zealand, but in Australia, where half-crowns are not in use, two shillings, should help the natural adoption of the new official term dollar. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1972 
Source: From Beads to Banknotes
Author: HARGREAVES
Vol / Page: 151
Edition: 
Quote: Half crown [:] half dollar, half bull
Notes: 

Date: 0/10/1977 
Source: NZ Numismatic Journal
Author: 
Vol / Page: 15
Edition: 
Quote: The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five  bob, and most familiar of all a dollar, ... The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull,  half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and two-and-a-buck. In the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only two bob being recorded as being in use in New Zealand.

See:

Citations 
Date: 0/0/1872 
Source: Edible Fishes
Author: HECTOR
Vol / Page: 118
Edition: 
Quote: This name is applied both to the SKIPPER (<I>Scombresox  Forsteri</I>) and to the Ihi or Half Beak (<i>Hemiramphus intermedius</i>) which are allied fishes representing those of the same names in the British seas.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1886 
Source: Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author: SHERRIN
Vol / Page: 33
Edition: 
Quote: GAR FISH (<i>Hemiramphus intermedius</i>). ... [34] This name is  applied both to the skipper (<i>Scombresox Forsteri</i>) and to the ihi or half-beak, which are allied fishes representing those of the same names in the British seas. The representatives of the former genus, however, though common in England, appear to be rare in these seas, while the half-beak, which is of rare occurrence in the British seas, is common all round New Zealand, and is the ordinary gar-fish that is so highly appreciated, especially in Auckland and Dunedin. <I>Ibid.</i> 40 HALF-BEAK (see GAR FISH).
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1956 
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 157
Edition: (2nd edn)
Quote: GARFISH or PIPER (TAKEKE) <i>Reporhamphus ihi</i> Phillipps. This fish is known in Auckland as Piper, although in Otago it is called Garfish or Guard Fish. ... It is on account of this peculiarity [a long bottom jaw] that they are sometimes called Halfbeaks. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1957 
Source: Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
Author: PARROTT
Vol / Page: 34
Edition: 
Quote: The name Half-beaks, which is generally applied to [garfish] in other countries, refers to their uniquely formed mouth, in which the upper jaw is normal, but it is the lower jaw which is produced into a long beak-like process. <I>Ibid.</i> 169 Garfish <i>Reporhamphus ihi</i> Piper; Guard-fish; Half-beak

half-bred
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:adjective
Sense Number:
Definition:of Maoris,  half-caste
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 22/5/1844 
Source: Diary
Author: TUCKETT
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: At each place which I have visited, I have been assured that the Maories are dying rapidly - `perishing like rotten sheep,' these people often say; thus at Kurreroo or Molineux, where there are now half-a-dozen natives, they say that formerly, and at no remote period, about two generations previous to the present, there were above a thousand; and in many other places within the last sixteen years, which is about the extent of the experience of the older beachers, there has been, in many places, a corresponding diminution of numbers. If this is an unexaggerated statement, it is a very distressing one to reflect on. Since Dr. -- visited this settlement, one of the residents, Mr. --, an educated man, has opened a school for half-bred or any other children, and the progress which the children have already made is very encouraging. 
Notes: 1844 May 22 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 223

Date: 21/10/1933 
Source: Press, The
Author: 
Vol / Page: 15
Edition: 
Quote: Halfbred sheep. Originally only applied to a sheep by a longwool ram from a merino ewe, but now loosely applied to the type. Corriedale sheep  were originally called inbred hb. Now in-bred hb. flocks are those which reintroduce merino or longwool blood, while he Corrie- dale flocks can only introduce Corriedale blood. (C.)
Notes: Acland Glossary

Date: 0/0/1936 
Source: Agricultural Organization in NZ
Author: 
Vol / Page: 416
Edition: 
Quote: This term [Half-bred] covers: (1) the progeny of any distinct breed of long-woolled ram mated with merino ewes; (2) the progeny of merino rams mated with any breed of long-woolled ewe; (3) the progeny from the mating of half-bred with half-bred. The wool produced by sheep from the above crossing is termed `half-bred' and ranges from 48's to 56's quality. 
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1987 
Source: Boards, Blades & Barebellies
Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Vol / Page: 96
Edition: 
Quote: Halfbred. Breed of sheep developed from the Merino and one of the long-wooled breeds - Leicester, Lincoln or Romney. It is a dual-purpose meat/wool sheep with emphasis on wool production. Has a fine to medium wool that sells well. Is mainly found in the South Island foothills but is sometimes grazed with Merinos in the higher regions of the Southern Alps. 
Notes:

Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1

Date: 14/1/1899 
Source: Sydney Bulletin
Author: 
Vol / Page:  (Red Page)

Quote:  (Loafer from Loafer, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]  Following are other local money-names...2.6d half  -bull, half-caser or two-and-a-buck... 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1972 
Source: From Beads to Banknotes
Author: 
Vol / Page: 151
Edition: 
Quote: Half crown [:] half dollar, half bull
Notes: 

Date: 0/10/1977 
Source: NZ Numismatic Journal
Author: 
Vol / Page: 15
Edition: 
Quote: The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five  bob, and most familiar of all a dollar ... The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull,  half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and  two-and-a-buck. In the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only two bob being recorded as being in use in New Zealand.
Notes:

I had in fact been thinking of one-pound loaves. ... But it took me sometime to remember that in Stewart Island,  one loaf meant four pounds of bread.

Date: 0/0/1926 
Source: Transport Workers' Song Book
Author: 
Vol / Page: 11
Edition: 
Quote: I'd tell them what I think o'them ... . . There's no half-pie about this kid- -->I have never heard the Part. use, or heard of it. Half-pie =half -' used frequently, and perhaps has Maori origin (check Wms), quotes Finlayson - Maori Nthland, and I have heard it frequy in Hlock.  Part cf pyah. `weak; paltry; inferior; useless.' mainly  naut. (1864) pye A contraction of pariah-dog: Anglo -Ind mily (-1886) Yule and Burnell.  P: Sup. pie-ard straight fr. the Hindustani comes the R.A.F. Regulars' nuance `any dog' (Jackson) The Army in Nth Africa (1940-3) used pie-dog of any desert dog. [all of which is muddy and contradictory: possibly pie a corruption or derivn fr. Hindi - check] 
Notes: 

half-pie
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:adjective
Sense Number:
Definition:imperfect; half-way; (neither one thing nor the other); mediocre (sometimes used to express an unsatisfactory incompleteness), (cf. its neither my arse nor John Jackson's); or else (ofmechanical things) merely = `half' cf 1950 quotation.  [poss. from Ma. pai good]. Half-and-half; half-way; (neither one thing nor the other); mediocre (sometimes used to express an unsatisfactory incompleteness), (cf. its neither my arse nor John Jackson's); or else (ofmechanical things) merely = `half' cf 1950 quotation. 
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date: 0/0/1966 
Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Vol / Page: 49
Edition: 
Quote: The word half-pie means `incompletely realized' or `only half'. It often occurs in inarticulate colloquial speech, very frequently with some speakers, as an equivalent of `sort of' or `kind of' when exact words will not come. Some derive it from Maori pai `good'.

Hamilton jetboat
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a boat propelled by a Hamilton jet unit, designed by Sir Charles William ("Bill") Fielden Hamilton [1899-1978].
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 23/6/1984 
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author: 
Vol / Page: 69
Edition: 
Quote: The books deals first with the experimental years in the development of the unit and jet boat in Hamilton's work shop... The book also recounts the development of different makes of jet unit following the success of the Hamilton jet unit overseas, particularly in America.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1983 
Source: Jet Boat
Author: BLOXHAM
Vol / Page: 1
Edition: 
Quote: A jet boat is a standard boat fitted with a car engine to drive a sophisticated pump or "jet unit". This draws water in through an intake in the bottom of the hull and forces it out at high pressure, jet-like, through a nozzle in the rear. Unlike a conventional boat, the jet boat has neither propellor or rudder. Instead, it is pushed along, and steered, simply by the thrust of the jet stream
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1983 
Source: Jet Boat
Author: BLOXHAM
Vol / Page: xi
Edition: 
Quote: For 30 years Sir William Hamilton's ‘jet boat' has given thousands of New Zealanders pleasure and excitement as well as useful commercial service

Vol / Page: 23
Edition: 
Quote: It was addressed simply: "Hamilton Jet Boat Inventor, New Zealand."

Hamiltonian

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1840 
Source: Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author: POLACK
Vol / Page: 1/202 fn
Edition: 
Quote: Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para[as-acute] <i>paraua</i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, <i>mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale, <i>tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, <i>mango</i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.
Notes:

Date: 21/10/1933 
Source: Press, The
Author: 
Vol / Page: 15
Edition: 
Quote: Hand.- Man employed. Seldom used without qualification, as  extra h., shed h., etc., except in the plural. Everyone  employed on a station is a s[tation] h., except the manager and cadets, and perhaps the cook. `All hands' and `all hands and the cook' are common expressions for `everybody' among the hands themselves. (C.)
Notes: Acland Glossary

handy dog
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a non-specialist working dog; a general-purpose sheep dog that will head, hunt, back, and perform.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 25/11/1933 
Source: Press, The
Author: 
Vol / Page: 15
Edition: 
Quote: Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work.The dogs that bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some  dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special  slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually slew (q.v.). (C.) 
Notes: Acland Glossary

Date: 0/0/1947 
Source: Wayleggo
Author: NEWTON
Vol / Page: 13
Edition: 
Quote: Occasionally one sees dogs that will both head and hunt equally well. They are known as handy dogs.
Notes:

Author:

Quote: HANDY DOG: A dog which can do both heading and huntaway work. A good one is a champion indeed.

Vol / Page: 5

Quote: So the musterer of to-day, with his pack of five or six dogs, began to take shape. One or two of the border type - `heading dogs' as they're called now and three or four huntaways and `handy' dogs. <i>Ibid.</i> 46 . . .Wait, the most wonderful dog I ever saw, a true `handy' dog. He wouldbring sheep out of any place where dog or sheep could go, and all his master ever said to him was `Here Wait! Here Wait!'; the rest was left to his own judgment and initiative and the sheep would be got.

Edition: 
Quote: hang of a/hanguva intensive regarding something big or forceful; euphemistic version of `helluva'; a fervent intensive favoured by juveniles; eg `That was a hanguva good flick, eh? NZA.  - like hang euphemistic phrase for `like hell'; eg `That was a hang of a good movie, eh?' `Like hang it was!' NZA.

The time of the day he started `hanging out' depended on a number of factors, including work pressure. He would have a minimum of three pings a day, a maximum of about six... When addicts are hanging out they will hassle around, do and pay anything to get a ping.

hangi
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:Native oven, consisting of a circular hole in the ground, in which the food was cooked by heated stones; the contents of a hangi; a) an earth oven, or its contents; b) a communal meal cooked in an earth oven:1979 HNZD;  =copper Maori, =umu.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1963

Author: BACON
Vol / Page: 181
Edition: 
Quote: hangi-Food cooked in a Maori oven. Such an oven, or umu, consists of a pit dug in the ground, part filled with large rounded river stones.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1963 
Source: O Te Raki
Author: KEANE
Vol / Page: 190
Edition: 
Quote: hangi: Maori oven consisting of a hole in the ground in which stones are heated by a fire. Branches and leaves (or, nowadays, sacks) are placed on top, sprinkled with water, and thenthe earth is piled on and stamped flat. The food is then steamed for several hours. 
Notes:

Source: Coal Flat

Date: 0/0/1982 
Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Vol / Page: 1
Edition: 
Quote: There are countless ways of preparing food Maori style, but basically there were only three ways of cooking it. The first, which  involves steaming in a subterranean oven called an umu or hangi, is known as tao cooking. It was the preferred method of cooking for groups of people, from family size up, in a village setting.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1982 
Source: Collins Concise English Dictionary
Author: 
Vol / Page: 508
Edition: 
Quote: hangi n. N.Z. 1. an open-air cooking pit. 2. the food  cooked in it. 3. the social gathering at the resultant meal. [< Maori]
Notes: [1986 NZPOD 341; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 224]

Vol / Page: Bk2/2/61
Edition: 
Quote: The Pakeha was much too valuable an animal in those days to be killed and eaten; that game did not pay at all. Cannibal feasts did come off now and again on the sly, but the Pakeha was too dear a morsel, and moreover, was far too salt to be put into a Hangi (native oven) for epicurean Maories. <i>Ibid.</i> Bk2/6/107 ... the steam was just arising from their hangis as these were being uncovered, and we were all soon served, each with a little freshly-plaited flax-leaf basket filled with most deliciously cooked kumeras, potatoes and peppies.

hangi stone
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a large stone, composed of rock which heats and holds heat quickly in an hangi or uinderground oven.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1982 
Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Vol / Page: 1
Edition: 
Quote: The ideal hangi stones are porous volcanic rocks, about the size of a fist, which are light and easily heated. Next best are the variety of metallic-coloured bluestone found in the Auckland area, or the dense riverbed boulders which are often found in deep mud. ... In some areas deposits of good hangi stones are rare, and in former times a set of stones was a welcome gift. 
Notes:

hangman's blood
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1978 
Source: Thoroughbreds Are My Life
Author: TUCKER
Vol / Page: 16
Edition: 
Quote: In our ranks was a very hard-headed gentleman by the name of Jensen who, on arriving at the pub, breasted up to the bar and ordered a `hangman's blood'. The barman confessed total ignorance of just what this drink might comprise. He was told to produce a beer handle, which he did, and was then ordered to go along [17] the entire length of the bar, putting in one nip of whatever spirits were on display. Now at that time spirits were very hard to come by, but Paul Rabone, the proprietor of the Mangatara Hotel, seemed to have an inexhaustible supply. Doing as he was bid the barman proceeded from one end to the other, putting in such things as scotch, gin, bacardi, rum, creme de menthe, and so on. He finally returned to the prospective quaffer of this incredible beverage with the beer mug about quarter-full of a purplish looking liquid. `Now,' said Jensen, `Fill it up with beer.'
Notes:

Notes: 

Date: 0/5/2003 
Source: NZ Geographic
Author: 
Vol / Page: N o. 63/58
Edition: 
Quote: Hansard takes its name from the Hansard family, which ran one of the many private-sector companies producing reports on House of Commons debates in the early  [60] 19th century. At the time, no official record was kept of what was said in debates, only of decisions made. Where the Hansards made their name was by producing their reports more quickly than their competitors did.

hapua
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a shallow lake
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 16/1/1844 
Source: Southern Districts of NZ
Author: SHORTLAND
Vol / Page: 219
Edition: 
Quote: From the spot where Huruhuru left us our path lay along a pebble ridge, with the sea on one side, and the lake Waihao on the other. This `hapua,' as all similar pieces of water are called, has no outlet to the sea except at times of floods, when one is made by the bank of pebbles breaking down at its weakest point: at other times its water oozes through the pebbles and sand. After leaving Waihao, which was nearly three miles long, we passed several small `hapua' similar to it. <i>Ibid.</i> 307 HAPUA, a shallow lake, the termination of a river, separated from the sea by a bank of sand or shingles. Syn. hopua.
Notes: 1844 Jan 16 in 1851 Shortland Southern Districts of NZ 219

Notes: 

hapuku
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:an important commercial fish =Cod 3b3 2b and grouper 2c. 1844 W Wakefield 1944 W & T Mod Jun Dice ed7 1960 Doogue & Moreland NZ Sea Angler guide 209 1946 JPS 1491966 Turner.] [Maori hapuku[a-micron].] Polyprion oxygeneios; 1. hapuku [`ha:puku] becomes English [ha:`puk],and a mishearing of Maori [p] phoneme gives the commonest pronunciation [ha:`buk]  2. whapuku [` a:puku] [`wa: puku] gives similarly [hwa:`pukd] [wa:`buk] etc. 3. Forms with no initial aspirate may be due to a) de-aspiration in vulgar English b) Maori dialectal de-aspiration (cf. Whangaroa - (North Island) Akaroa (South Island) initial. In more Maori districts the stress is often on the initial syllable, as in Maori, but in NZ colloquial it is more usually on the second syllable; the Eng. plural can have an -s inflexion; Obsolete (and sometimes mistaken) names include:  (New Zealand) cod, cod-fish, rock cod;  formerly called New Zealand cod,  =groper.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date: 0/0/1882 
Source: Brighter Britain
Author: HAY
Vol / Page: 2/151
Edition: 
Quote: In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga). <I>Ibid..</I> 2/ 231 We prefer the substantial schnapper, the goodly whapuka or kanae, or the luscious poraki. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1884 
Source: TrNZI
Author: 
Vol / Page: 17/419
Edition: 
Quote: The fishing off the island is very good, there being abundance of hapuku, kokiri, kohikohi, maumau [sic], schnapper, kahawai, tarakihi, in addition to plenty of shell-fish such as koura or crayfish, crabs, paua, etc. The mako shark, so well known for its beautiful teeth, which are highly prized by the Maoris as ornaments, is found off this island and nowhere else in the world I believe, ...
Notes: (Goldsmith)

Date: 0/0/1885 
Source: TrNZI
Author: 
Vol / Page: 17/198
Edition: 
Quote: The fish for eating are hapuka,<i>Oligorus gigas</i>; rock cods, <I>Percis colias </I>; tarakihi, <I> Chilodactylus macropterus </I>; moki,  <I> Latris ciliaris </I>, etc.,etc. 
Notes: (Reischek)

Date: 0/0/1886 
Source: Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author: SHERRIN
Vol / Page: 40
Edition: 
Quote: HAPUKU (<i>Oligorus gigas</i>). The first on the list of marketable  fishes is the hapuku, or whapuku of the Maoris (<I> Hectoria gigas </I> of Count Castelnau), or habuka, as the name is generally pronounced by Europeans, who in the south, apply the name groper to the same fish. It is also occasionally called the cod-fish, which is altogether erroneous, as it is more properly the representative of the sea-perch of European seas. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1892 
Source: NZ Official Handbook
Author: 
Vol / Page: 167
Edition: 
Quote: Of the sea-fishes that are used as food in New Zealand, we have among the constant residents on all parts of our coast the hapuku, tarakihi, trevally, moki, aua, rock-cod, wrasse, and patiki; and while the snapper, mullet, and gurnet are only met with in the north, the trumpeter, butterfish, and red-cod are confined to the south.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1892 
Source: TrNZI
Author: 
Vol / Page: 24/203
Edition: 
Quote: 2. <I> Mokohinou Islands </I>. - Hapuku (or groper), hiwihiwi, barracouta, maomao, spotty, parrot-fish, leather jacket, korokoro-pounamou. <i>Ibid.</i> 24. <I> Puysegur Point </I>- Hapuku, kahawai, trumpeter, moki, pig-fish, trevally, rock-cod, perch, butter-fish, red-cod, dog-fish
Notes: (Thomson)

Date: 0/0/1898 
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 192
Edition: 
Quote: <I> Hapuku </I>... Maori name for a fish, <i>Oligorus gigas</i>, Gunth., called later <I> Polyprion prognathus </I> (see quotation, 1895), pronounced  hapuka, frequently corrupted into habuka, the Groper  (q.v.). It is variously called a <I> cod,</I> a <I> Perch </I>, and a  <I> Sea-Perch </I>. See quotations.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1938 
Source: Nor the Years Condemn
Author: HYDE
Vol / Page: 234
Edition: 
Quote: Starkie never struck trouble but once, when he asked  [on the transtasman boat] for some <I> hapuka</i> at breakfast. A very young English steward commanded: `You cut out that language in front of the women.'  `I asked for <I> hapuka.  Hapuka</I>. Just plain  <I> hapuka</i>.' `There you are,' yelled the steward. `He said it again. Said it three times.' ... `For Christ's sake,' said the chief steward wearily: `Get him some fried fish.' `Fish? Is that all it means? I thought , in front of the women . . .'  `In front of the women or behind their backs,  <I> hapuka's</i> still fish and fish is still <I> hapuka</i> fathead,' explained Starkie, ... 
Notes:

Vol / Page: 224
Edition: 
Quote: GROPER or HAPUKU ... <I>Other names: Polyprion oxygeneios</I>; whapuku (Maori). Groper has a wide usage in the South Island, while hapuku is largely used in the North Island. The word `hapuka' is a corruption of hapuku.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1967

Author: MORELAND
Vol / Page: 52
Edition: 
Quote: HAPUKU or GROPER [<I>Polyprion oxygeneios</I>] ... Hapuku is a Maori name widely used by North Island fishermen, while groper has a predominantly South Island usage. In some localities both names are used.

Date: 0/0/1970 
Source: Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author: SORENSON
Vol / Page: 26
Edition: 
Quote: <i>GROPER</i> (two species) (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Polyprion oxygeneios</i> (ii) <i>Polyprion moeone</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) New Zealand Groper; Hapuku (ii) Bass. (c) Other common names: (i) Hapuka, Stone-eye, Blue-nose, Bonita (ii) Deepsea Groper. (d) Principal localities where taken: [Mainly easten coasts, Foveaux, and Chathams] ... [27 Groper and Bass] should not be confused with the Australian and tropical groupers which they resemble superficially.

Date: 0/0/1842 
Source: New Zealand (Heaphy)
Author: HEAPHY
Vol / Page: 48
Edition: 
Quote:  [<i>Abuka </i>, (Chatham Islands) -->apuko] Amongst those esteemed the most, the <i>Abuka </i> ranks first. It is generally of great size, but the flesh is of much delicacy of flavour. A considerable quantity of it is cured at the whaling stations for winter provision, and is very fine. I have seen this fish being carried along the beach of Wellington, on a pole, borne by two natives, who found its weight fully equal to their united strength. [124] The same fish that are found on the coast of New Zealand may be caught in plenty in Port Wakefield [Chatham Islands] ... The great apuko, the snapper, ... <I>Ibid.</i> 124 The great apuko, the snapper, and the crayfish, are very numerous ... 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1843 
Source: Travels in NZ
Author: DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page: 2/222
Edition: 
Quote: Polack mentions `cod-fish', bearing the native name of `Wapuka,' but we do not know the fish he alludes to. The `polach' he speaks of are, perhaps, the young of the <i>Percis colias </i>, the adult of which are known to the settlers as the `cole-fish'.
Notes: 1842 Gray's Fauna (Richardson's Fish)  in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/222

Vol / Page: Indulgence (supplement) /20
Edition: 
Quote: There are two species: Phormium tenax, also known as harakeke, whararahi or swamp flax; and Phormium cookianum, also known as wharariki or mountain flax. ... Harakeke can be differentiated from wharariki by its larger size and seed pods.

Date: 28/9/2002 
Source: Dominion Post
Author: 
Vol / Page: F15
Edition: 
Quote: Outside the home of every self-respecting Irish peasant in days gone by would be a small patch of flax, grown to be spun and woven into linen for household use. We're not talking about harakeke (New Zealand flax), of course, but the totally unrelated European flax (Linum usitatissimum)... When Europeans arrived in New ZXealand, they called harakeke "flax" because its fibres are similar to those of Linum.

hard bar
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1907 
Source: NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
Author: 
Vol / Page: 4(NS):101
Edition: 
Quote: The country rock separating two veins approximately parallel with each other has, in certain instances, been found to grade laterally from the vein-wall, where it assumes a highly propylitic facies, to a median rib of dark and only slightly altered rock. Theseribs or dyke-like masses are the `hard bars' of the miners. In some cases, however, these `hard bars' are probably due to dykes. <i>Ibid</i> 111 The `hard bars' of mining terminology are in most cases merely remnants of less-altered rock, but occasionally as in the case of the `bar' mentioned in the Golden Pah mine, they owe their existence to intrusives. 
Notes: (Fraser and Adams, Coromandel)

Date: 0/0/1948 
Source: NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
Author: 
Vol / Page: 42(NS):39
Edition: 
Quote: Further, the `hard' bars most probably interrupted the shoot, more of less horizontally.

Date: 0/0/1982 
Source: Stewart Island Plants
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 456
Edition: 
Quote: <i>Blechnum</i> HARD FERNS ... They are easily recognized also by their hard texture and simply divided fronds. In some species young fronds are striking red or pink. <i>Blechnum</i> is a predominantly southern hemisphere genus of some 200 species; Stewart Island has 12, which is about three- quarters of the New Zealand total.  <i>Ibid.</I> 460 <i>Blechnum</i> sp. `brown scale' Common hard fern ... Fronds more or less tufted but commonly covering extensive areas of open forest floor ... Frond scales uniformly brown.  (ii) <i>Paesia scaberula</i>  pig-fern, ring-fern, silver fern.

hard lines
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:Common esp. in constr.  it is (was etc.) hard lines on (a person, thing), to connote `hard going'; `hardship, hard times',  be hard on = `fall heavily on' (hard = `difficult') rather  than OED Line `6. ill luck, bad fortune (Prob. nautical in orig; now often associated with 4c).' 4c. Appointed lot in life (in echoes of Ps. xvi 6). OED quots for 6 (1824) are similar to the NZ quots, given below cf COD lines 2.

hard shot
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:NZ since ca1930 (Slatter).] a) (informal) an unorthodox, amusing, or incorrigible character; a dag. b) a person hardened by experience; ?Transf. from shot `one who shoots; an expert in shooting', often qualified by aj (good, bad shot) (cf good, bad sport)  cf OED 22, esp 22b. (a queer shot) dial., an `odd customer'. good shot occas. used in NZ for `good sport', good boy: e.g. (a grandfather speaks) `Be a good shot now and get me my slippers';  =hard case.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Quote: hard shot law unto self, fiercely independent; eg `Frank's a real hard shot, no question. Lost everything in the fire, wasn't insured, won't accept help from anybody.'

Word Class:verb
Sense Number: 1
Definition:to graze a paddock or pasture closely or heavily to stimulate growth. 
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/1/1961 
Source: NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author: 
Vol / Page: 241
Edition: 
Quote: Similar treatment during November after the area has been hard-grazed with cattle (not sheep) will account for most of the older and mature plants.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1966 
Source: Sheep Farming for Profit
Author: DU FAUR
Vol / Page: 57
Edition: 
Quote: Paddocks to be conserved, usually those near the homestead, should be hard-grazed early in the autumn to permit good recovery before winter.
Notes:

hash
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:usu. humorous or ironical for inferior food badly-prepared or badly-served, not necessarily chopped up chiefly in compounds in NZ : dry hash, hash-foundry, hash-house, hash-me-gandy; hash-up; hash is Std E. (cf OED sb1, and COD), and specific uses may be dialect : cf EDD. from Nhb `sheep's lights boiled then minced small  and stewed with onions'.; or NZ (Dry Hash) chopped or minced left-overs, heavily seasoned or spiced, and baked without liquid; food. 
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

Pronunciation:

Vol / Page:

Quote:

Date: 0/0/1949 
Source: Dictionary of Slang Addenda
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 1072
Edition: 
Quote: Hash-me-gandy. Station stew: New Zealand and Australian rural: since ca. 1920. B., 1942, suggests: ex Mahatma Gandhi's frugal meals.  An elaboration of hash
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1957 
Source: Canterbury Frozen Meat Company
Author: MACDONALD
Vol / Page: 7
Edition: 
Quote: In the early eighteen-nineties digesters were installed for `boiling down' the offals. ... This was essentially a stewing process which took four to six hours' cooking, and separated the fat by partial breakdown of the animal tissues. The residue, or `ashmegandy', was dried in a machine for fertiliser material, as was the blood. 
Notes:

hatch tent
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1964 
Source: Watersiders
Author: DAVIS
Vol / Page: 97
Edition: 
Quote: `Right, up we go and put the tent on. The rain's gathering a bit of weight.' A hatch tent consists of a large, light tarpaulin which islashed down round the hatch coaming while its centre isheld up by a wire strung fore-and-aft across the hold. Itprovides effective temporary cover for an open hold, saving the time and labour required to replace the more cumbersome permanent hatch covers.

Date: 10/7/1868 
Source: Letters from Canterbury, NZ
Author: HARPER
Vol / Page: 143
Edition: 1914
Quote: Some of the men [are], in mining phraseology, `Hatters', that is men who live and work by  themselves content with the solitude of well kept huts, a few books [etc] ... .<i>Ibid.</i> [144] hard work, their dog as companion, perhaps some poultry, and a weekly visit on Saturdays to the townships to sell their gold and see friends. Whence the term `hatter' I have never discovered; maybe because such solitaries are regarded as `mad as a hatter.' 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1948 
Source: Julius Von Haast
Author: VON HAAST
Vol / Page: 529
Edition: 
Quote: By one of these [West Coast] `beachers,' a countryman of mine, we were most hospitably entertained, the table being covered with several luxuries of the season which I did not expect in the abode of a `hatter' who are generally of a morose character, and do not indulge in any comforts of life.
Notes: 1868 Von Haast in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 529

Date: 0/0/1873 
Source: Wild Will Enderby
Author: PYKE
Vol / Page: 3/vii/95
Edition: (1889,1974)
Quote: He was what is termed in mining phraseology, a `hatter', - meaning one who works by himself. ... Alone and unaided he scooped the wash-dirt into his cradle, which he vigorously rocked with his left hand, whilst with the right he ladled water from the river into the `hopper' or seive [sic]. ... He cast aside the `dipper', and hastened towards the eddy.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1874 
Source: Colonial Experiences
Author: BATHGATE
Vol / Page: 138
Edition: 
Quote: Hatter: Whatever the origin of the phrase, `as mad as a hatter' can have been, I have often unsuccessfully endeavoured to discover. But doubtless it is from this phrase that the name of hatter has come to be applied in mining parlance, to one who works alone or without a mate. There are always a few of these unsocial miners about every digging, and their solitariness arises from every imaginable cause. Frequently they are misanthropes, sometimes placid contented creatures, who, so long as they can make a living by `fossicking' about, are happy. / [139]. My host was a hatter and he always kept a spare stretcher for any chance passer-by.  
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1876 
Source: Colonial Travel
Author: KENNEDY
Vol / Page: 189
Edition: 
Quote: These [holes] frequently form the grave of some unfortunate `hatter', as a man who works alone and has all his property `under his hat' is called [in Central Otago]. 
Notes:

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1967 
Source: West Coast Gold Rushes
Author: MAY
Vol / Page: 527
Edition: 1962
Quote: HATTER: a solitary, a digger who works alone. The derivation of this New Zealand expression is obscure. Archdeacon Harper described the hatters as `men who live and work by themselves, often old sailors and much travelled men, content with the solitude of well-kept huts, a few books, hard work, their dog as companion, perhaps some poultry, and a weekly visit on Saturdays to the townships to sell their gold and see friends. Whence the term `hatter' I have never discovered; maybe because such solitaries are regarded as `mad as a hatter'. Another possibility is suggested by the remark that the hatter `kept his whole world under his hat'. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1968 
Source: NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins)
Author: 
Vol / Page: 10
Edition: 
Quote: hatter n.prospector who works alone.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1983 
Source: Gold Fossicker's Handbook
Author: NOLAN
Vol / Page: 112
Edition: 
Quote: Hatter: miner who works alone. Probably derived from the habit of such men of leaving their hats at the surface to indicate that they were working down the mine shaft.  
Notes:

hatter
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:extended to other occupations, a solitary person
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 28/10/1933 
Source: Press, The
Author: 
Vol / Page: 17
Edition: 
Quote: Hatter. One who works and camps by himself. Originally a miner's expression, no doubt from the saying of a man without relations that he had `all his family under his hat'. Archdeacon  Harper derived the word from `mad as a hatter' (Letters, p. 143). The word is in general use on stations. H.'s billy, tent, etc., one just large enough for one man. ([1898 MorrisAustral-English])
Notes: Acland Glossary

Quote: ENTELEA ARBORESCENS (<i>Brown</i>.) ... The `WHAU', or `HAUAMA'.- This very beautiful small tree is peculiar to the Northern Island of New Zealand, but is not common. ... Owing to the extreme lightness [61] and bouyancy of the wood, the tree is known to the Colonists as the `Cork Tree'. <I>Ibid.</I> Hauama [Maori name] .. Cork-wood [Settlers' name] .. Entelea arborescens .. Small tree

Definition:have a beer in, have a fly, have a look-in, rat (in one's garret), have a set on, have a spite on, have for breakfast, have had it in a big way, have one's photograph taken, have on toast, have the goods on, have tickets on,  have whacked; see beer, fly, look-in, rat, set, spite, breakfast, had it, photograph, toast, goods, ticket, whacked. 
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

have a cramp in one's kick
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:to be short of money (in the pocket)
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:kick
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1879 
Source: Spangles and Sawdust
Author: WHITWORTH
Vol / Page: 5
Edition: 
Quote: I was down there with Old Ashmore's lot, doing the trampoline, and so on; but things was very quizby. Everything went crooked somehow, and the gorger had a hawful cramp in his kick. Well, ramp was the word, and vamose we did, the lot on us; some here, some there. I was reg'lar beached, and I tell you when a cove 'as to spout his smish it's about time to look out. However, I got a job at a livery stable, but although that kep' me in grub, and I slep' in a spare stall, the billet was very multy, and I kep' on the kivvy for something better. [fn] 1. [trampoline] Vaulter. 2. [quizby] Bad. 3. [crooked] Wrong. 4. [cramp in his kick] Emptiness in his pockets. 5. [ramp] Clear out. 6. [vamose] Go. 7. [beached] Hard up. 8. [smish] Shirt. 9. [multy] No good. 10. [kivvy] Look out (qui vive.)
Notes:

have a pop at
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:have a go at, engage in a fight
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1988 
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 87
Edition: 
Quote: <i>pop</i>, phr. <i>have a pop at</i> a fight; NZA. <i>- to go off pop</i> to start speaking angrily. <i>- not a fair pop</i> not a fair chance; eg `I'd like to have a pop at the little basket, but I apologise for going off pop at you. It's not a fair pop you having to be involved.' c. 1925.
Notes:

Witness: `A screw loose.' His Worship: `I don't understand you.' Witness: `He seemed to have a rat in his garret.' His Worship: `Oh, speak English!' Witness: `Off his dot - balmy [sic] - dilly.' Sergeant: `He says the man was mad, your Worship.' Witness: `No, I didn't. I said he was either drunk or ratty.'

have for breakfast
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1937 
Source: Dictionary of Slang
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 379
Edition: 
Quote: <I>Have for breakfast</I>. occ. <I>before breakfast</I> (as a rare appetiser). A humorous way of implying that a thing is easy to do, (gen.) a man easy to beat. E.g. `Why! I have one like him every day before breakfast' or `I could have <I>or</I> done with six like him for breakfast.' For task or feat, the <i>before breakfast,</i> often with <i>do</i> or <i>have</i>, is preferred. C. 20 coll.: mostly Australia and New Zealand.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1988 
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 21
Edition: 
Quote: <i>breakfast</i> in phr. <i>have for breakfast</i> find some person or thing easy to overcome or achieve; eg `Just let him try anything. I'll have him for breakfast.' NZA mostly.
Notes:

have the wood on
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:to have the/an advantage over, to have the upper hand of: possibly f. tree-falling or axemen's contests, where one wins because one is a chip or thickness of wood ahead of an opponent who loses because he still has a piece of wood to sever before his trunk or block falls: but cf. ADD, and the googs on 
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Quote: Among the terms which are of considerable use to us in our daily life, for instance, is <i>to have the wood on a person,</i> to have an advantage over someone.

Quote: <i>Wood on, have the. </i>`To have an advantage over someone' B., 1941): New Zealand: since ca. 1920. Either rhyming <i>have the goods on </i>or ex the game of bowls.

have tickets on
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:to be keen on (a person); espec. to set one's cap at a man or woman to have a special interest in, to be courting. -->(from a fig. use of ? to put one's personal label or ticket on (to claim possession of or to warn others off); or from ? having a raffle ticket on with hope of winning [but raffle tickets are usually in not on a raffle].

Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

Pronunciation:

hawk
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:Usu. novaeseelandiae, occas. <i>Circus approximans</i>.  See falcon, harrier; also kahu, karearea. See also  fish-hawk (Caspian tern); sea-hawk (southern skua). [Spec. and strictly erroneous use of hawk--> a diurnal bird of prey of the sub fam. Accipitrinae to various similar NZ birds.

I have sometimes at night given a stud lamb up for lost, left it in a hay box on the laundry floor and gone to bed, to be awakened in the small hours by the bleat of a lamb wanting milk.

Quote: [Hdg] Handy haylage. Empty hay sheds are becoming a familiar sight on lower North island farms as farmers discover the convenience of haylage... Haylage is plastic wrapped in convenient bales, keeping it preserved for longer... Haylage is simple to make. There is no pit to dig as there is for silage and the cut grass is only left lying for 24 hours.

haymaking
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:working a beach claim for gold
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1866 
Source: Letters from Canterbury, NZ
Author: HARPER
Vol / Page: 100
Edition: 1914
Quote: [goldfields] They give me a shovel and, with it nearly full of sand, direct me to shake it gently in the water till all the sand has gone, and then round its rim is a thin line of gold, fine as dust, enough to cover a threepenny bit. This is the easiest way of getting gold, so easy, it is called `Haymaking,' but it will not last long, as the black sand brought down by the river, with its gold,from the mountains, and cast up on the beach, where it has lain for centuries, is of limited extent. [Also in -1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 10
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1967 
Source: West Coast Gold Rushes
Author: MAY
Vol / Page: 222
Edition: 
Quote: When they come upon one of the rich spots, the fine particles of gold being often visible to the naked eye, they at once remove the black layer of sand out of reach of the tide, and wash it when convenient.* ... [fn] This method of working the beaches was also called `haymaking' or `beachcombing'. These terms were not applied to beach-workings above high-water mark. 
Notes: 1868 Haast in 1967 May West Coast Gold Rushes (1962) 222

Hay's curse
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a species of ; a garden weed.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 7/6/1952 
Source: Personal Communication
Author: R. MASON
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: Hay's curse: A species of oxalis. I heard this in 1933 from T.L. Lancaster who was head of the Departtment of Botany Auckland University College. Hay's Nurseries were well known and old established nurseries in Auckland, still going then, but I believe since closed down. I am not certain of the particular species but the plants have pinkish flowers and produce large numbers of tubers and of corms, by which it spreads and which are almost impossible to get rid of! I understand that Hay introduced the plant into N.Z. It is the only time I have heard the name used, and imagine that it was then obsolescent.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1972 
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 175
Edition: 
Quote: Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

Date: 28/10/1933 
Source: Press, The
Author: 
Vol / Page: 17
Edition: 
Quote: ~ (1) People do not as a rule say (e.g.) `fifty cattle'  but `fifty h. of cattle'. Up country people usually confine this idiom to cattle and sometimes horses. But I see to-day in `The Press' (June 27, 1933)  the editor speaks of a decrease of so many h. of sheep disclosed by this year's sheep return. (C.) (2) A dog goes round to the far side of  a mob of sheep and stops them. This is called heading. Hence  heading dog, one whose work this is. If he does it neatly he  makes a good h See also sheep dog. 3. The owner would say, `I can  head with him'.(C; [1874 Kennaway Crusts],p. 45)
Notes: Acland Glossary

Citations 
Date: 0/0/1947 
Source: Wayleggo
Author: NEWTON
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: Stopping dog: A heading dog which, once it has headed sheep, will just lie and hold the mob until its master arrives. The ordinary heading dog will endeavour to `pull' the sheep. In early days when high country sheep were much wilder and longer heads occasioned stopping dogs - real specialists at straight-out heading - were common.
Notes: [glossary]

He made a beautiful head and flopped on his belly about ten yards from the sheep ...

Date: 0/0/1962 
Source: Waikaka Saga
Author: EVANS
Vol / Page: 8
Edition: 
Quote: `When other and more accurate means of measuring water are not conveniently available, it may be done by using gauge boxes of the dimensions ... `The gauge box shall be 12 feet long, 20 inches or 40 inches wide, inside measurements ... in accordance with the undermentioned table ... In other words, if the depth of the pressure above the board, above the top of the aperture, is five inches, the aperture is twenty inches wide, and two inches deep, the number of sluice heads discharged is one.'

Notes:
Citations 
Date: 18/12/1856 
Source: Diary
Author: W.H.S. ROBERTS
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: At Macfarlane's the men saddled fresh horses and rode in some cattle which we had a great bother to yard, as everything was new ... The yard was divided into three - one large and two small - but as there was no crush pen, or drafting race, we had to head rope those requiring branding, and after hauling them up to a corner post, leg-roped and threw them on [44] their side, placing a long lever on their neck and under the lowest rail so that they would not move much ... When released the poor beast is not in an amiable temper ... So anyone in the yard has to climb the rails quickly ..., and the idea that it may catch you before your legs are safely over the cap rail certainly accelerates one's movements.
Notes: 1856 Dec 18 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 43

head-ditch
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:a central or feeder ditch in a furrow irrigation system. 
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 20/8/1924 
Source: NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author: 
Vol / Page: 108
Edition: 
Quote: In the furrow method of irrigation small furrows or corrugations are made in the direction of the slope and connected with a head-ditch supplying water .. Water is taken from the head-ditch, which follows approximately the contour of the surface, into the distributing-furrows, which may be parallel with the ditch or diverge from it. In turning the water from the head-ditch into the furrows the common practice in Central Otago is to make openings in the lower bank with a shovel.
Notes: 

Date: 20/8/1924 
Source: NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author: 
Vol / Page: 115
Edition: 
Quote: One of the most frequent and heaviest operations in the preparation of land for irrigation is the formation of head-ditches.

headframe
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition:

See:

Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1978 
Source: Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author: McARA
Vol / Page: 324
Edition: 
Quote: Headframe: The poppet-head erected above a shaft was also called a headframe. It had to be very strong to withstand the shock and weight of two cages plus the weight of over 1000 ft of heavy wire-rope, with a wide margin of safety, and high enough to allow double-deck cages to be used if necessary and to have at least 10 ft clearance above the detaching hook to the detaching-ring. Most of the headframes were of steel but Nos 5 and 6 were of kauri timber. The back stays were placed midway in the angle between the winding-rope and the line of the shaft.

heading
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:

Domain:[none]

See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 28/10/1933 
Source: Press, The
Author: 
Vol / Page: 17
Edition: 
Quote: ~ (1) People do not as a rule say (e.g.) `fifty cattle'  but `fifty h. of cattle'. Up country people usually confine this idiom to cattle and sometimes horses. But I see to-day in `The Press' (June 27, 1933)  the editor speaks of a decrease of so many h. of sheep disclosed by this year's sheep return. (C.) (2) A dog goes round to the far side of  a mob of sheep and stops them. This is called heading. Hence  heading dog, one whose work this is. If he does it neatly he makes a good h See also sheep dog. 3. The owner would say, `I can head with him'.(C; [1874 Kennaway Crusts],p. 45)  
Notes: Acland Glossary

heading
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:(sheepdog trials)
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1966 
Source: Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author: McLINTOCK
Vol / Page: 1/493
Edition: 
Quote: Heading. In the long head the competitor stands with his dog in a ring (1 chain in diameter) facing a hillside near the top of which three sheep are set loose.  When time is called the dog is dispatched, either on a left-hand or a right-hand cast, up the hill for some 800 yards to a point behind the sheep. On command the dog `lifts' the sheep and, keeping them together, `pulls' them in a direct line back to his master in the ring. To allow the dog to show complete control over the  sheep, the run ends with a `hold in the ring'. This involves stopping the sheep in the ring and holding them there. The first stages of the short head are much the same, but over half the distance, 400 yards. At the point where the sheep reach the shepherd, man and dog must drive them ahead down a `drive' which is 60 yards long and 1 chain wide and defined by short poles, to a set of hurdles which are 9 ft apart and parallel with the line of the drive. The sheep are driven between the hurdles and then down a second drive, similar to the first, to the pen or yard, which is 6 ft square. After opening one side, the competitor must stand by the pen gate until the sheep are yarded. The dog must do virtually all the work and his master's right of movement and intervention are strictly limited.
Notes: 

heading
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
