Date: 0/0/1905 
Source: Where the White Man Treads
Author: BAUCKE
Vol / Page: 75
Edition: 
Quote: An old-time bay whaling station consisted ... of at least two boats, with their crew of six men each. The headsman, or mate, four ordinary oarsmen, and the harpooner, or `boat-steerer,' who pulled the bow-oar, and drove in the harpoon, and who, when the whale had been struck and `fastened on,' went aft and steered the boat, while the mate took his place, and by repeated  lance-thrusts killed it.

Date: 0/0/1939 
Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE

Quote: After the All Blacks had beaten Wales in the first match of their grand slam, I was startled to find a sports writer lambasting commentator Murray Mexted for applying the word "heady" to rugby, when "heady", in his view, only meant things like "intoxicating" etc.  News to me.  Phrases like "He plays a heady game" or He's a heady player" have been in New Zealand sporting vocabulary all my life, meaning "thinking, intelligent, or analytical".

Date: 0/0/1997 
Source: John Banks : A Biography
Author: 
Vol / Page: 22
Edition: 
Quote: With a background like this, Banks was a candidate for the health camps. Set up after World War One, they were originally intended for malnourished and tubercular children. After World  War Two they specialised in children who were nervous, solitary and emotionally troubled... We would never admit to the other kids that we were going to a health camp, because, supposedly, any kid who went to health camps was diseased.

Date: 0/0/1879 
Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author: HAAST
Vol / Page: 114
Edition: 
Quote: Fortunately there were many shrubs of <I>Dracophyllum longifolium. </I> growing in this locality, which even in their green state burn freely, and which enable the traveller in those regions, so much exposed to rain, to light a fire with comparative ease. This plant has needle-shaped leaves, generally of a brownsh tint,and small bell-shaped white flowers. It [115] is generally called a native heath by the Europeans. As some of the bushes grow to a height of ten feet with thick branches, it offers wood enough to keep up a cheerful fire.

heckler's veto
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition:

Domain:[none]

See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 29/11/1984 
Source: Evening Post
Author: 
Vol / Page: 2
Edition: 
Quote:  [Hdg] Media react to `heckler's veto'/  Are the views and `messages' of these [special interest pressure groups] being given undue prominence too often? Are they tending to beat into the ground opposing views, equally or more valid but less well organised? Are they imposing, in fact, a form of censorship. ...  The term `heckler's veto' was coined by the incoming president of the Auckland Council for Civil Liberties in September. He was publicly voicing concern over the action of police in seizing anti-Black pamphlets from the pro-white Nationalist Workers' Party.

Quote: It's hellashin funny.  1978 editorial note 191: `hellashin'. Originally in the expression `hellashin hot' to match `perishing cold'. The more aceptable variations were `hangashin' and `heckashin'.

There grows spontaneous every where a kind of very broad pladed [sic] grass like flags of the nature of hemp of which might be made the very best Cordage Canvas etc. There are two sorts [sic] the one finer than the other, of which the natives make cloth, rope, lines, netts etc. [Footnote: the New Zealand flax or Phormium tenax].

Date: 23/5/2004 
Source: Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine)
Author: 
Vol / Page: 15
Edition: 
Quote: Many a bathroom is home to a hen and chickens fern, <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i>, but did you know that its unfurling koru can be steamed, slathered in butter, seasoned with pepper and salt and served on toast for a quintessentially Kiwi brunch?
Notes:

Author: 
Vol / Page: No. 49/76
Edition:

Author: MARTIN
Vol / Page: 103
Edition: 1961
Quote:  The HEN AND CHICKEN FERN (<i>A[splenium] bulbiferum</i>) is a ubiquitous species in New Zealand forests ... Under humid conditions, small plants may be observed growing from near the tips of the pinnae, whence popular name.

Notes: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)

Date: 0/0/1981 
Source: NZ Medicinal Plants
Author: BROOKER et al.
Vol / Page: 25
Edition: 
Quote: <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> Forst f. Common name: <i>Hen and chickens fern</i> Maori names: <i>Mauku, mouku </i>... `Mauku' has been identified as <i>Asplenium bulbiferum, Cordyline pumilio</i>, and <i>Hymenophyllum</i> spp. by Williams and as <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> by Best. `Mouku' has been identified as <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> by Williams and as <i>Marattia salicina</i> by Tregear. <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> is a common fern throughout New Zealand forests.

Author: THOMSON
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: Pastor Wohlers, long a missionary working among the natives on Ruapuka in Fovaux Straits, states that mice were first brought to the island in the `Elizabeth Henrietta', which was wrecked there in 1824, and that even as late as 1873 they continued to be known as `henriettas'.
Notes: (R. Mason)

Henry
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1949 
Source: I Saw in My Dream
Author: SARGESON
Vol / Page: 140
Edition: (1974 ed. Rhodes)
Quote: At the war there were Froggy soldiers that always carried round little boxes - just little wee things less than the size of a matchbox. And inside there was a model of Christ on the cross - just a tiny thing. And over the top there was a word you could hardly read but it looked like H-E-N-R-I.  Well, Mr Anderson said, I could never work it out why they were called Henrys - that's what us diggers called them, little Henrys. D'you know, I've always meant to ask somebody why they were called that name.  And it was on the tip of Dave's tongue to explain, but he thought no. Because he'd have to explain why the I's weren't J's, and --[note 271:] ... His explanation of `little Henry' would have been based on I.N.R.I., Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews, from Lat. Iesus Nazarenus, Rex Iudaeorum.
Notes:

Homonym Number: 
Word Class:adjective
Sense Number:
Definition:

Notes:
Citations 
Date: 15/7/1911 
Source: NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author: 
Vol / Page: 1/26
Edition: 
Quote: A striking case of the value of testing the individual members of a herd is reported from a district where a herd testing association has been established. 
Notes: 1911 July 15 NZJAg 1/26 in 1966 Turner 45 

Date: 0/0/1936 
Source: Agricultural Organization in NZ
Author: 
Vol / Page: 26
Edition: 
Quote: The herd-testing movement is worthy of special mention. Practically 20 per cent. of the dairy cows in the Dominion are tested for butter-fat production monthly during the milking season. <i>Ibid.</i> 346 Although herd testing and milk recording societies existed in Germany, Denmark, England and other countries many years earlier, systematic herd testing appears to have been first developed in New Zealand about the year 1920, when a model Herd Testing Association was established by the New Zealand Department of Agriculture in the Wairarapa. 
Notes: 

herd-testing
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the testing of dairy herds for disease, or to estimate milk production, etc. 
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 22/1/1927 
Source: NZ Dairy Produce Exporter
Author: 
Vol / Page: 35
Edition: 
Quote: We have been rather keen on herd-testing in this district and most folks [get] the herd-tester to do their cows.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1920 
Source: Dairy Farming in NZ
Author: POWDRELL
Vol / Page: 46
Edition: 
Quote:  Herd-testing. - It is strongly maintained that herd-testing - the periodical recording of the weight of each cow's produce together with a butter-fat test from which data the production of the cow for the period is calculated - is the surest way of distinguishing the drones ... 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1936 
Source: Agricultural Organization in NZ
Author: 
Vol / Page: 28
Edition: 
Quote: As the result of herd testing, greater attention to culling and breeding and improved farm management, the average butterfat yield per cow increased from 154.25 lbs. per annum in 1920-21 to 218.80 lbs. per annum in 1929-30. <i>Ibid.</i> 345 The major function of Herd Testing is primarily to determine the milk and butterfat producing ability of individual cows, and from this information to secure accurate data for the elimination of low-producing cows and also to provide a more scientific basis for the breeding of dairy stock. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1966 
Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Vol / Page: 45
Edition: 
Quote: A cow with `a good test', that is, milk rich in butterfat, may be more valuable than another cow that gives more milk. About 1910 the practice rose of smpling milk from all the cows in a herd individually and testing the milk for its fat content. This process is called herd-testing. ... It is still not decided whether the word is hyphenated or not. I find it without a hyphen in a publication of the Department of Agriculture in 1950,  with a hyphen in a textbook of dairying in 1955. Pronunciation is with one stress, on herd. <i>Ibid.</i> 149 In New Zealand, everyone usesthe term herd-testing, not  milk-testing, because everyone thinks of the dairy industry from a producer's, not a consumer's, point of view.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1974 
Source: NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author: 
Vol / Page: 92
Edition: 
Quote: Herd testing helps farmers to maintain the standard of their herds - it shows up the lower producers so that they can be culled from the herd. 
Notes:

heron
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:[Spec. use of heron for any of several large wading birds with long necks and legs, of the fam. Ardeidae.]

Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:also crane; kotuku, matuku(-moana).

Date: 0/0/1970 
Source: Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author: SORENSON
Vol / Page: 10
Edition: 
Quote: ANCHOVY  (a) Scientific name: <i>Engraulis australis</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Anchovy. (c) Other common names: the following names of related Clupeids and Engraulid fish are sometimes applied to anchovy - Herring, Sprat, Sardine, Pilchard, although the true Herring of European waters  (<i>Clupea harengus</i>), does not occur in New Zealand. (d) Principal localities where taken: Hauraki Gulf, Gisborne, Tasman Bay, Marlborough Sounds.

Date: 0/0/1872 
Source: Edible Fishes
Author: HECTOR
Vol / Page: 114
Edition: 
Quote: 58. SEA MULLET. ... The Makawhiti or Aua of the Maoris  (<i>Agonostoma Forsteri</i>) ... is a common fish ... It is commonly called Herring, from its general resemblance in size and form to that fish, but is easily recognisable from the true Herring by having two fins on the back, ... The Picton Herring, a dried fish commonly known roughout the colony, is the Aua preserved bysmoking.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1886 
Source: Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author: SHERRIN
Vol / Page: 65
Edition: 
Quote: MAKAWHITI (<i>Agonostoma Forsteri</i>). ... Called the sea-mullet in other places, but the makawhiti or aua by the Maoris. It is a common fish, Dr. Hector says, obtained at all seasons of the year by fishing from the wharves in the harbours. In Dunedin it is known as the mullet. ... The Picton herring, a dried fish, commonly known throughout the colony, is the aua, preserved by smoking.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1956 
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 104
Edition: 
Quote: PILCHARD (MOHIMOHI) <I>Sardinops neopilchardus</i> (Steindacher) The Pilchard is known from the northern end of the South Island as the Picton Herring, and off Picton large shoals of these fish have from time to time been recorded. It has no relation to the so-called New Zealand Herring or Yellow-eyed Mullet (<i>Agonostomus forsteri</i>).

Date: 0/0/1986 
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: PAUL
Vol / Page: 40
Edition: 
Quote: <i>Pilchard  Sardinops neopilchardus</i> ... Sometimes called the sardine. Also occurs around southern Australia. ... In the 1880s a fishery in the Marlborough Sounds produced salted and smoked `Picton Herring', and small fisheries have developed briefly elsewhere. ... Pilchard are caught for groper bait (`bloater'), and have been used also for tuna.

Vol / Page: IV/115
Edition: 
Quote: EMMELICHTHYS NITIDUS (Richardson). <i>Red bait-fish</i>. Rare, and only occasionally utilized as a food fish. Taken in seine among mackerel, and commonly known as `red herring'. Distribution: I have recorded specimens only from the northern coasts of the South Island. 
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Date: 0/0/1981 
Source: Fisherman's Bible
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 35
Edition: 
Quote: BAITFISH, RED <i>Emmelichthys nitidus</i>: A less common species in New Zealand waters this fish turns up unpredictably in vast schools that give the water a red appearance - and the fish its name. Grow up to about 16 inches and known also as picarel, pearl fish and red herring. Colours light pink to dark red.

herring
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:an anglicisation of a Maori rendering (hereni [hereni]) of Eng. `shilling,' with the -ing from Eng. shilling, the whole approximated  to the Eng. word herring also herren.

Author: 
Vol / Page: IV/120
Edition: 
Quote: AGONOSTOMUS FORSTERI (Bloch and Schneider). <i>Common Mullet; Aua</i>. Common in the estuaries of all tidal rivers, often entering fresh water in the summer. Called `herring' at Golden Bay and on the west coast of the South Island, but not identical with Picton herring. ... Distribution: New Zealand harbours and estuaries. 
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Source: Natural History of Canterbury
Author: SPEIGHT
Vol / Page: 198
Edition: 
Quote: Mugiloidea. An intermediate stage in the forward movement of the pelvic fins is represented in the little sea-mullet (<i>Agonostoma forsteri</i>  (Plate I. fig. 2)), popularly known as `herring.' It is a shore and estuarine form and feeds on the small shrimps which come in with the tide. 
Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 198

Date: 0/0/1966 
Source: Sea Anglers' Guide
Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND
Vol / Page: 220
Edition: 
Quote: YELLOWEYE MULLET ...<i> Other names: Aldrichetta forsteri</i>; herring, common mullet, sprat; sea mullet, river mullet (Australia); aua (Maori). The name herring in widely used in New Zealand for the yelloweye mullet but the true herring is a very different kind of fish. There are two species of true herring in our waters.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1967 
Source: Marine Fishes
Author: MORELAND
Vol / Page: 48
Edition: 
Quote: YELLOWEYE MULLET [<i>Aldrichetta forsteri</i>] ... Other names are herring, common mullet, and sprat. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1970 
Source: Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author: SORENSON
Vol / Page: 39
Edition: 
Quote: <i>MULLET, YELLOW-EYED</i>  (a) Scientific name: <i>Aldrichetta forsteri</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Sea Mullet; New Zealand Kipper (smoked); Rollmops (pickled). (c) Other common names: Herring (in error and best dropped); Common Mullet; Sprat (in error). (d) Principal localities where taken: Tauranga, Kaipara, Lake Ellesmere. ... The name `Herring' has been applied widely and for a long time to the New Zealand Yelloweyed Mullet which is not a Clupeid and therefore only very distantly related to the true Herring of European waters. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1970 
Source: Way Up North
Author: THOMAS
Vol / Page: 24
Edition: 
Quote: The Maoris knew to a nicety when to expect the Aua, or herring, or to be correct, the yellow eyed mullet ...
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1981 
Source: Fisherman's Bible
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 120
Edition: 
Quote: HERRING More often than not a Yelloweye Mullet, but the fish that is widely known as the `herring' in our coastal waters. Also known as `sprat', though this term also covers the young of several species including anchovy, yelloweye mullet and several other small fish. There areonly two, `true' herrings in our waters. <i>Ibid.</i>164 The Yellow-Eye has a much narrower head than the Grey and is the ubiquitous, but misnamed `sprat' or `herring' of our wharves. 
Notes: 

Date: 23/7/1986 
Source: Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Author: 
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: [species name] herring .. [scientific name] -- [other name(s)] This may be SPRAT [<i>Sprattus antipodum</i>] or YELLOW-EYED MULLET [<i>Aldrichetta forsteri</i>]; Hastings region = Yellow-eyed mullet.... [species name] sprat .. [scientific name] <i>Sprattus antipodum</i> .. [other name(s)] sardine, herring

Sense Number:

Sense Number:

Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Author: 
Vol / Page: 39
Edition: 
Quote: Herringbone cowshed. Cows are milked in two rows standing at an angle to the milker who is in a pit at udder level. Cup put on from the side. All the cows enter and leave together.

Date: 0/0/1977 
Source: Journal of Tussock Grasslands Inst.
Author: 
Vol / Page: 36
Edition: 
Quote: The high country is the area east of the Southern Alps consisting of properties at high altitude with extensive grazing which are subject to severe weather hazards such as snow loss.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/2001 
Source: Calling the Station Home
Author: DOMINY
Vol / Page: 142
Edition: 
Quote: .. the Grasslands Division of the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research (DSIR) defines the South Island "high country" in "agricultural terminology" as a remote area of high-altitude pastoral Crown leasehold land occupied by large sheep stations, or runs .. The New Zealand Meat and Wool Board's Economic Service defines the South Island high country similarly as "extensive run country" and calculates the carrying capacity in Canterbury, Otago and Marlborough as 0.9 stock units per hectare. Distinguished from the South Island high country is South Island hill country, characterized by a larger proportion of lowland soil, lower snow risk and less dependence on wool as a source of income ...
Notes:

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1952 
Source: Land Uplifted High
Author: PASCOE
Vol / Page: 162
Edition: 1961
Quote: The speech of the men is a slow drawl, sometimes flavoured with Scotch burr ... [fn] High country slang on sheep runs has national characteristics such as referring to a man as a `joker',and using the adjective 'crook' to describe bad weather or ill health, eg `I felt crook on the day the crook weather brought the river up'. Regional slang is also of interest, such as use of `dag' (literally wool fouled with sheep's dung) to mean a `hard case' or unusual character, with an implication of approval, even of admiration. `Rooster' is another variant of `joker'. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1960

Domain:[none]

See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1938 
Source: TrRSNZ
Author: 
Vol / Page: 68/416
Edition: 
Quote: <i>Helicolenus percoides</i> (Richardson). Sea perch, so called John Dory (scroddie, fivefinger, soldier-fish, Jock Stuart, Higlander). 
Notes: -->1938 TrRSNZ (Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour)

Date: 0/0/1956 
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: 
Vol / Page: 344
Edition: (2nd edn)
Quote: SEAPERCH (POHUIAKAROA) JOCK STUART, HIGHLANDER, FIVEFINGER,  SOLDIERFISH or SCRODDIE <i>Helicolenus papillosus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) The seaperch is a fish well known to all fishermen both sports and commercial fishermen alike, who give it quite a number of vernacular names, a few of which are as follows: Jock Stuart, Highlander, Fivefinger and soldierfish. These names have a bearing on some distinguishing characteristic of the fish. For instance the first two names are supposed to be given on account of the colouring of the fish resembling, in some ways, the tartan of a Scot; ...  
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1888 
Source: Birds of New Zealand
Author: BULLER
Vol / Page: 1/14
Edition: 
Quote: ... to say nothing of Korimako and Pitoitoi ..., we never saw or heard the notes of either the Piopio, the Tieke, or the Hihi, all of which birds were at one time more numerous even thanthe Huia. The <i>Zosterops</i> was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail.

Vol / Page: 9/485
Edition: 
Quote: [Native or Common Name] Hiku, Frostfish ..  [Scientific Name] <i>Lepidopus caudatus </i>
Notes: (P. Thomson, Otago)

Date: 0/0/1886 
Source: Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author: SHERRIN
Vol / Page: 29
Edition: 
Quote: FROST FISH (<i>Lepidopus caudatus </i>). ... [30] The frost-fish, or hiku of the Maoris, is esteemed the most delicious fish in New Zealand. It is most commonly found cast up after cold frosty nights on sandy beaches that are exposed to the long roll of ocean swell, and is not in this country obtained by any kind of fishing. <i>Ibid.</i> 300 <i>Lepidopus caudatus </i> Euphrasen Frost-fish, Hiku, or Para 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1886 
Source: Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author: SHERRIN
Vol / Page: 29
Edition: 
Quote: FROST FISH (<i>Lepidopus caudatus </i>). ... [30] The frost-fish, or hiku of the Maoris, is esteemed the most delicious fish in New Zealand. It is most commonly found cast up after cold frosty nights on sandy beaches that are exposed to the long roll of ocean swell, and is not in this country obtained by any kind of fishing. <i>Ibid.</i> 300 <i>Lepidopus caudatus </i> Euphrasen Frost-fish, Hiku, or Para

hill country
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:high ground, esp. when used for sheep farming; steep to rolling country (usu. with only a small proportion accessible by wheeled tractor; and in NZ usu. land previously covered in bush), a mainly NI use.Cf. [1984 Frame Angel at My Table 175 `That's the Mount.' [Maunganui] I had grown used to the North Islanders' reference to hills as mountains.]  Compare high country.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Quote: The children soon afterwards began to cram themselves with  hinau cakes, - a black, filthy mass, consisting of the fruit [24] of the hinau tree compressed together, and kept till quite rottenand musty, which they eat with avidity.
Notes: 

Date: 1/8/1850 
Source: Journal
Author: TAYLOR
Vol / Page: 7/115
Edition: 
Quote: One of the women of the pa ... presented my natives with two hinau cakes tied up in leaves. In former days this was a kind of food which was very much admired and considered most excellent ... It is of a dark olive color and it is of this that the saying is used, that no one has aright to awake his neighbour in the night except it be to feed him with hinau bread. 
Notes:

Date: 0/0/2006 
Source: Internet - see Notes
Author: 
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: Many trampers today like the flexibility of planning their own routes, of not having the pace set by others. Some are put off by the "hisser" mentality, which is apparently still alive in some clubs. Hissers sprint from point to point, seeing nothing. At the hut they bore everyone senseless with their boasts about record times. 
Notes: http://masseynews.massey.ac.nz/magazine/stories/going_bush.html    Accessed 1 Mar 2006.

Date: 0/9/1958 
Source: Tararua
Author: 
Vol / Page: 29
Edition: 
Quote: Visitors to Wellington comment on the brisk pace of the pedestrians, and Wellington trampers  have achieved a certain notoriety for the speed with which some of them travel in the hills. It is not surprising,  therefore, that its hillmen and hillwomen should hiss along, that hissers and little hissers should flourish, and that little hisser should sometimes be used as a term of approbation - `stew a  hisser', `a real hisser of a day'. The Tramper first gives to hiss in 1934, and hisser with reference to a stew appears on 1940, but to a person not until 1943, though it must have been so used long before.
Notes: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

Date: 0/0/1988 
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 56
Edition: 
Quote: hisser term of approval, mostly among trampers, in such contexts as `a hisser of a day' or `a hisser of a stew'.

historic hut
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:any of a large number of older back-country huts built for mustering, tramping, etc.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/2009 
Source: Internet - see Notes
Author: 
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: The back country of New Zealand contains a heritage of about 1400 huts that is unequalled anywhere in the world. These huts were built for the following reasons: wild animal control (~750) sheep mustering (~500) recreation (~150) a range of other purposes including prospecting, scientific studies and castaway sustenance. Others began life as schools and homes and later became huts. These huts have heritage value as the only physical remnant of these activities. ...DOC is identifying a representative selection of key historic huts that can be managed long term to conserve this heritage and allow its appreciation. It is intended to have interpretation signs provided for each historic hut.
Notes: www.doc.govt.nz/conservation/historic/historic-heritage-topics/huts

hiwi
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:spp., inanga, whitebait.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1927 
Source: Bibliography of NZ Fishes
Author: 
Vol / Page: 13
Edition: 1971
Quote: <i>Galaxias attenuatus </i>(Jennyns). MINNOW; HIWI or INANGA. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1956 
Source: NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author: GRAHAM
Vol / Page: 118
Edition: 2nd
Quote: MINNOW or WHITEBAIT (INANGA) <i>Austrocobitis attenuatus</i> (Jenyns) ... For a long time it has been known to the Maori and to Europeans that our New Zealand Whitebait is the young of a native freshwater fish commonly known as Minnow, or Inanga or Hiwi to the Maori, and erroneously called a Trout. ... The early settlers called it Maori Trout, Native Trout, Rock Trout and Minnow. But it is not a Trout. Nor is it a Minnow, through it resembles the English freshwater Minnow. While the name Trout is not correct, it is and will always be known as such by farmers and naturalists. In the Bay of Plenty, Whitebait is known to the Maori as Porohoe. 
Notes:

Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:we communicate/correspond with (post to) Hobart, (Melbourne), a euphemism for `Tatts ticketssold here';  to post to, to be in touch with Hobart, to sell (then illegal) tickets in Tattersall's lottery; notices in tobacconists' etc. shop windows: `We post to Hobart' to sell tickets (illegally) in Tattersall's Tasmanian Lottery; see also Tatts, ticket. 
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1980 
Source: Indirections
Author: BRASCH
Vol / Page: 408
Edition: 
Quote: A little news-agent's window on Plimmer Steps, ... bore the same message in its oracular pronouncement that  We Communicate Weekly with Hobart. 
Notes: [1940's]

Date: 0/1/1951 
Source: Here & Now
Author: 
Vol / Page: 25
Edition: 
Quote: `We communicate with Hobart every week' [heading]
Notes: 

Date: 0/1/1952 
Source: Here & Now
Author: 
Vol / Page: 31
Edition: 
Quote: their realisation staked on the/ still intangible ticket from Hobart./ 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1966 
Source: Austral English
Author: TURNER
Vol / Page: 175
Edition: 
Quote: The Golden Kiwi was established partly to prevent money being sent out of New Zealand for tickets in Tatt's, a Tasmanian lottery with a name abbreviated from Tattersall's and quite unconnected with the English cant word tatts `dice'. It was illegal to sell tickets in Tatt's in New Zealand but many barbers' shops displayed a notice, `We communicate with Hobart', which wasuniversally understood.... It was clear that in the context of a barber's shop window the notice meant `we sell tickets in Tatt's', but legally a man can announce that he writes to Tasmania. Newspapers might report the good fortune of winners but the illegal source of the winnings would not be specified. The money came from `an overseas consultation'. 
Notes:

Irwin, who quotes a tramp's C. 20 distinction: `Bums loafs and sits. Tramps loafs and walks. But a hobo moves and works, and he's clean.'

One of the hobos gurgled, and said, `Want to make an impression on that pretty icicle, ...'.  Jim quietly replied `Thanks for your advice, but I donot want any information from `hobos' nor even from `quadroons'.'  `Hell! call me a half-caste?' flushed the main offender, sitting opposite. ...  `Dad is very taken with you, and with the fact that you skittled those Maori hobos has tremendously advanced your stocks. ...'

Definition:a gen. term usu. used to describe young pigs. May be used for castrates or barrows but not specific (American) (CCR notes: US not young: a domestic swine weighing more than 120lbs).

hog weed
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:wireweed
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1926 
Source: Weeds of New Zealand
Author: HILGENDORF
Vol / Page: 61
Edition: 1967
Quote: WIREWEED (<i>Polygonum aviculare</i>), also called road weed, mat weed, knot grass, [pig weed,]  and hog weed, is common in cultivated land all over the country. It is an annual, with stems up to 2ft. in length trailing over the ground. The stems have swollen nodes (`knot grass') and are very tough (`wireweed').
Notes: 

Date: 23/7/1970 
Source: Dominion
Author: 
Vol / Page: 15/1-3
Edition: 
Quote: The news from Britain that hogweed or cow parsnip as it is more commonly called, has been added to the list ... The New Zealand Weed and Pest Control society in recent publication `Standard common Names For weeds in New Zealands' records the name cow parsnip withoutgiving the specific name. This plant could be H. sphondlylium a native of the British Isle and at one time widely advocated as a suitable stock food because of its thick fleshy tap root. Hogweed in New Zealand is a popular descriptive name for four different weeds. Two of these, namely the twin cress and wart cress, belong to the same genus. The other two are the wild portulaca and wire weed, which are in no way related. The popular names of the latter illustrate how confusingthe use of names like fire weed or wandering willie can be as a means of identifying weeds and plants. These common names of plants frequently have only local significance and in cases may even become obsolete. For this reason botanical names are ... 
Notes:

hogget
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:In NZ used widely on and off (esp. for the meat) the farm (cf hog n1.) (note that animal and meat definitions differ); a) a young sheep between weaning (4 months) and first shearing(14-16 months). b) meat from a yearling sheep between 14 and 24 months.

Domain:[none]

Edition: 
Quote: ~ 8 temporary teeth - centre pair of permanent teeth start to erupt about 12 months... Hogget: Young sheep between weaning (4 months old) and 14-16 months of age. The hogget stage usually ends when the animals are shorn (around 14 months old). There are ram hoggets, ewe hoggets and wether hoggets.

Date: 0/0/1982 
Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Vol / Page: 104
Edition: 
Quote: New Zealanders are alone in distinguishing hogget from lamb or mutton. Lamb is the meat of any animal from six weeks until it grows its first two teeth, from which time it becomes hogget. When a full set of teeth is grown, the meat from the sheep becomes mutton. 
Notes: 

Date: 13/11/2003 
Source: Dominion Post
Author: 
Vol / Page: C6
Edition: 
Quote: Each year, he buys in 1000 replacement ewes as hoggets amd two-tooths, going out of his way to source the best genetics.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1987 
Source: Boards, Blades & Barebellies
Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Vol / Page: 94
Edition: 
Quote: Ages of sheep. Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A sheep is a lamb until weaned. After weaning a lamb  is called a hogget until shorn. A male lamb is a  ram lamb until castrated, then a wether. A female  lamb is a ewe lamb. After shearing, a ewe or ram  lamb is usually called a shorn hogget until  cutting the first two teeth. It is then called a two-tooth. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a  four-tooth, then a six-tooth and then an  eight-tooth or full-mouthed sheep. It is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy
Notes: 

Date: 0/11/2001 
Source: Cuisine
Author: 
Vol / Page: 132
Edition: 
Quote: I got two bob a week pocket money and for that, I had to feed the chooks, collect firewood, dag the hoggets, dynamite the swamp and drench the bulls.
Notes: Daryl Crimp

hogget
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a hogget carcass comes from a sheep between 12 and 24 months of age, i.e. from yearling sheep. -->2. (butchers') Of meat from hogget; but often as a general (or euphemistic) term for mutton (on hotel menus, etc) (R. Mason).

hogsback/hogback
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:1. a long, sharply crested ridge. 2. a similar shape, especially a cloud heralding a northwest storm in the SI mountains.

Edition:

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1940 
Source: Peaks, Packs & Mountain Tracks
Author: GILKINSON
Vol / Page: 25
Edition: 
Quote: ... he showed me a hogsback and told me what it meant. [fn] Term applied to a particularly unwelcome cloud only too well-known to climbers, and almost invariably heralding a north-west storm. An unpleasant sight - but a valuable weather sign.  
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1945 
Source: Camping and Bushcraft in NZ
Author: HARPER
Vol / Page: 39
Edition: 
Quote: The most infallible warnings of a nor' wester are the very high clouds of a peculiar torpedo shape, with a hard, rounded upperside like a whale's back - `hog backs' is the usual name among alpine men.
Notes: 

Date: 0/9/1958 
Source: Tararua
Author: 
Vol / Page: 27
Edition: 
Quote: It is scarcely neccessary to mention the well-known hogsbacks, those torpedo-shaped clouds which form on the east side of the Southern Alps during a nor'wester and presage bad weather in the ranges, so [28] named by the late A.P. Harper. ... <I>Ibid.</i> 40 From our camp on the grassy meadows some battled their way up to the snowline, retreating pellmell when they came face to face with a herd of hogsbacks; ...

Vol / Page: 161
Edition:

Quote: GENYPTERUS BLACODES (Bloch and Schneider). <I>Ling; Hokarari.</I> A deep-water fish, to be secured during all months of the year. Common around Stewart Island and the South Island generally. Distribution: Taken as far north as the Bay of Plenty and Hauraki Gulf where it is considered rare.

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1957 
Source: Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
Author: PARROTT
Vol / Page: 159
Edition: 
Quote: The Ling was known to the Maoris as Hokarari. Some years ago ago large catches were made in Cloudy Bay, and were placed on the Wellington market as `Cloudy Bay Cod'. The scientific name <I>Genypterus blacodes</I>, freely translated, means `a flabby fish, with a fin on the chin.' The New Zealand Ling is also found in Australia where it is known as the `Rockling.'

In the Southand in some parts of the North Island itis identical, apparently, with the"hakuwai" which has seven joints in itswing, lives in the sky, and presagestrouble... "Its cry was Hokioi! Hokioi!Hu!" The last word represented thewhizzing sound made by the bird inflight.

Hokitika swindle
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:(also Hokitika ellipt.) a hotel bar game, orig. popularised on the West Coast (at Hokitika), but known throughout NZ.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1941 
Source: NZ Slang
Author: BAKER
Vol / Page: 57
Edition: 
Quote: The Hokitika Swindle is an hotel bar game played in order to create a jackpot from which payment of drinks may be made. It is based on a method of counting, whereby the personwho calls a certain number in sequence pays a specified sum into the jackpot [or shouts the round].  
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1949 
Source: Dictionary of Slang Addenda
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 1077
Edition: 
Quote: Hokitika swindle. `Hotel bar game played to create a jackpot from which payment for drinks may be made,' B., 1941: New Zealand: C. 20. Of topical origin.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1988 
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 57
Edition: 
Quote: Hokitika swindle calling of a certain number in sequence with the aim of creating a jackpot, which is used to buy rounds of drinks in a pub. 
Notes: 

Date: 23/9/1953 
Source: Evening Post
Author: 
Vol / Page: 16
Edition: 
Quote: `Hokitika' Game Led To Fight. A fight outside a hotel in Lower Hutt follow[ed] a game of `Hokitika.' ... In a statement to the Police Parascuk said that `Hokitika' consisted of guessing the numbers on a 1 [pound] note. He lost 15/- this way and accused Cloake of cheating.

Hokonui
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:a wild, fine-wool Merino-type breed of sheep that has roamed the Hokonui Hills in Southland. 
Origin:toponym
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1987 
Source: People, Places & Paddocks
Author: GORDON
Vol / Page: 103
Edition: 
Quote: For Leon that's meant ducks, for Lynley, her hokonui flock, and all of them have a few Coopworths ...
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1987 
Source: People, Places & Paddocks
Author: GORDON
Vol / Page: 101
Edition: 
Quote: Hokonui sheep are out of the same hills [as Hokonui whisky] and although not illegal, are certainly a curiosity. A fairly original form of Merino, they've run wild for well over a century and have developed, or reverted to, quite a few distinct characteristics. There's the varying shades of black, brown and grey with a wee dash of white on the forehead and a white tip on the tail...'They're just different,' he says. 'Things like positioning of bones and teeth, everything from the traditional farm animal breeding world, you can forget about when it comes to Hokonuis. They're as tough as old boots and interesting in their grazing habits. They prefer rough feed and will eat heads and thistles before they touch the clover.'..Interested though he is, there's no way Peter will reduce the Coopworth flock in concession to the Hokonuis.
Notes: 

Date: 0/2/2008 
Source: Growing Today
Author: 
Vol / Page: 58
Edition: 
Quote: The first record of the feral Hokonuis was in 1863, a flock of about 200 animals, so they have had 150 years to adapt. The Hokonuis' ancestors are believed to be smooth-skinned Saxony Merinos .. When and how Hokonuis came to be here is unlikely to be proven.
Notes: 

Date: 30/6/2007 
Source: Internet - see Notes
Author: 
Vol / Page: 1
Edition: 
Quote: Whenever I hear the words wild sheep I instantly think of the Hokonuis in Southland ...
Notes: www.fishnhunt.co.nz/issues.cgi?action=hand&forum=32&thread=3387&msgid=1&query=1

Date: 5/8/1936 
Source: Auckland Weekly News
Author: 
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: [NB: Invercargill went dry at 10 p.m., 30 June 1906 to 1946] There is nothing unpleasant or poisonous about the genuine `Hokonui' manufactured in the forest of the mountain range from which its name is derived. It sells at a price considerably lower than the imported article on which duty was paid, and some connoisseurs regard it as better than Scotland's best.'

Hokonui Swindle
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:error for Hokitika swindle, a bar-game played with the numbers on bank-notes.  ca1974 Wellington: used in De Brett hotel bar
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 19/10/1983 
Source: NZ Times
Author: 
Vol / Page: 3
Edition: 
Quote: Included in Hodges's  study is the truly macho battle of alcoholic consumption - the drinking game. ... There'll be some inane feat of manliness to perform, such as a lewd tongue-twister, or a physical show of strength, and he who loses has to down his glass in a gulp. In Otago alone, Hodges found 42 varieties of the theme, with names such as `One Fat Hen and a Couple of Ducks' or the `Hokonui Swindle'.
Notes: 

Date: 13/3/1988 
Source: Dominion Sunday Times
Author: 
Vol / Page: 16
Edition: 
Quote: Other well-known [drinking] games are Hokonui Swindle, Bottles, Fluffy Ducks, Bunnies are Hovering, Cardinal Huff, All Blacks, Matches, and The Amazing Grimaldi Brothers. All these games involve either a complicated intellectual exercise, tongue twisters, mathematical calculations or aerobatics in a confined space; High Candelabras for example, involves intoxicated individuals attempting to traverse the four walls of a room without touching the floor. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1989 
Source: Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 45
Edition: 
Quote: Hokonui Swindle more recent name for and/or version of the Hokitika Swindle, a pub game aimed at financing further drinking. Baker identified the Hokitika version as based on a method of counting `whereby the person who calls a certain number in a sequence pays a specified sum into the jackpot'. Glenn Johnston defines the Hokonui version as a drinking game that combineselements of chance with the ability to hold your liquor and follow a few simple rules - though the deviousness of the caller can also influence proceedings. The aims are simple: to liven things up, get a bit of alcohol consumed quickly and sort the stayers from the pikers.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 166
Edition: 
Quote: Many kinds of dogs have been introduced by the Colonists; including  Bull-dogs, by the whalers, Kangaroo-dogs, (a mixture of greyhound and mastiff) from New South Wales, and various crosses between these and the natives' dogs, which go under the general name of  pig-dogs, and combine courage with speed, being used chiefly to hunt the wild hog, and taught to hold him, when caught, by ear or jowl, until the hunter comes up.

Date: 0/0/1937 
Source: Dictionary of Slang
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 397
Edition: 
Quote:  holding, ppl.adj. In funds: Australian:C. 20: s.> coll.  See hold, 4. [To be in funds: low coll. ...:at first, Cockney:  from ca 1870. In C. 20, mostl;y Australian. Esp. in do you hold?,  C. 19, and, C. 20 Australia, are you holding?] Esp. How are you holding?, how much money have you?: also New Zealand.

Quote: fn `To bottom a hole,' is a peculiar expression used on the mines in Australia; it means to convey the sinking of a shaft down to the bed-rock on which the auriferous drift generally rests. 
Notes: 

Date: 23/6/1887 
Source: Chudleigh Diary
Author: 
Vol / Page: 356
Edition: 1950
Quote: 
Notes: Got samples [of quartz] from several holes to take away and have assayed. 

Date: 0/0/1887 
Source: Taken In
Author: HOPEFUL
Vol / Page: 135
Edition: 
Quote: [Colonial slang] If a man isn't `up to the mark' he is called `a regular shicer!' This phrase originated from the gold diggings. Supposing a man is digging, but without success, and he therefore abandons his hole, it is called a `shicer' - that is, the  ground was called a `shicer' or duffer, thus the origin. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1914 
Source: Diggers' Story, The
Author: PFAFF
Vol / Page: 115
Edition: 
Quote: I bought and sold flour ..., got a 3-1/2 oz. nugget from the bottom of a hole that had been left, made a rise of [pounds]300 out of a pocket of gold like horse beans.

Date: 0/0/1946

Author: MILLER
Vol / Page: 69
Edition: 
Quote: I was on gold all the time. I had sunk my first prospect hole at the lower end of a shallow depression ... and had struck the deepest part of the lead. It was a narrow gutter, no more than afoot wide at the most, and rich in heavy gold.

Quote: `Treasure' I played ringie and holie. I played funs and keeps. I had pee-wees and bully taws and changers that weren't made of glass mind you. And I won nearly every game because the kids were so dazzled by the look of my stinkers. ... They came for miles to play marbles with me ... 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1953 
Source: Unorganized Games
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 2/719
Edition: 
Quote: There is only one record of a New Zealand game in which a formal penalty element entered. This was a game of marbles called Dumps and was played at Wakefield in 1875. In this game the loser, in a marble game of Holey, was required to hold his marble partially exposed between the fingers of his closed fist [for others to shoot at]. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1972 
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 174
Edition: 
Quote: In the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (In more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There was Big Ring, in which a circle a yard or more in diameter was drawn on the ground; there was the mullibar variation, in which an outsize taw was catapulted amongst the marbles in this circle. There were Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. The last was more usually a girls' game. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1984 
Source: NZ Yesterdays
Author: KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page: 288
Edition: 
Quote: ] [Photo caption] Marbles became `in' or `out' capriciously but someome always knew the rules of the various games - `holey,' `liney' and, seen here, `ringey' - which could be played for `funs' or `keeps.'

Source: Numismatic History of NZ
Author: SUTHERLAND
Vol / Page: 66
Edition: 
Quote: In New South Wales, in 1813, this difficulty [of shortage of coin] became so acute that Governor Macquarie, in an effort to check the outflow of Spanish dollars, then the main circulating medium, caused the centres of these coins to be struck out, the centre-piece (about the size of a shilling) being stamped NEW SOUTH WALES, 1813, around a central crown, and on the other side FIFTEEN PENCE, the remainder or `ring' part of the dollar being impressed around the new inner rim with NEW SOUTH WALES, 1813 on one side, and FIVE SHILLINGS on the other. ... [67] 3,008 Dollars (mainly Holey or Ring Dollars) [pounds] 752 0 0/ 725 Dumps (centres of Spanish Dollars) 45 6 3

Quote: The boys learnt a form of wrestling called `Collar and elbow' brought by miners from Lancashire. A Cumberland form of that sport was not so popular. In `Collar and elbow' theopponents clutched one another in strange `holts' - a right hand grasped an opponent's left  shoulder, the other hand grabbed his adversary's right elbow.

Date: 0/0/1981 
Source: History of Children's Play
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 230
Edition: 
Quote: I remember two essentially Maori games, Cat's Cradle and Homai, but the others were all traditional English games I think, ... (1912-20; Ohau) <I>Ibid.</I> 231 There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. West Coast: Dunk and Davey, Spang Weazling; Wellington: Who Goes Round My Stone Wall, Beg o' My Neighbor, Bellahonie, Run a Mile, On and Off the Bridge, Here Come Two Nuns, Colours, Isaac and Rebecca. Scrag, Diabolo, Bumble Puppy, Homai, Fives; Auckland: My Fair Young Lady, Rushes and Reeds, Surrender the Tower, Walls, Ball Hopscotch, ball games, Solomon Says; Hawkes Bay: Wolf Wolf Go Home, Homai; Canterbury: Poor Old Tom, Rats and Rabbits and Rips, Steps, Skin the Snake, Steal a Peg, Toodle-em-Buck, The Gag; Golden Bay: Who's That Walking Round My House Tonight, I've Come to See Poor Mary Jane, Steps and Stairs, Creeping, Branding, O'Leary;  Otago: Sir Roger de Coverley, Who's That Knocking at My Door.

Homaiacky
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a former children's game
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1953 
Source: Unorganized Games
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 2/513
Edition: 
Quote: Of the Help-He games, Kick the Tin, is the most widely known. A tin is placed in the centre of a circle. One He is in charge of the tin. He can only tag the other players when his tin is in the centre of the circle. Any players he catches must stay in the circle. Any non-caught player can help and free the other caught players by running through the circle and kicking the tin out of it. Other names for this game are: Kick the Boot (Gisborne [18]90), Knock the Block or Homaiacky (Nelson [18]95), Kick the football or Piacky (Mangatainoka). 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1972 
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 80
Edition: 
Quote: In a few tagging games the players joined hands with the He when they were caught and helped him catch the other players. These games were known as  The Bellahonie (E-21) (Wellington, 1910), Kick Post One (Hampden, Otago, 1880), and Ballyhooley (Wellington, 1920). More popular were those games in which the players helped one another to fight the He, and of these the most widespread was the game known as  Kick the Tin (e-3), Kick the Boot, Kick the Block, or Homiacky.  In this game the He was put on guard of a jam tin placed inside a small circle marked on the ground. [Other players hid: those He could see he named and tapped the tin three times and `captured': other hiders waited till they had chance to kick tin out of circle: then all were free again.] 
Notes:

Vol / Page: 5
Edition: 
Quote: Mr. Fyfe had found a moa's egg, at the Kai Koras, while digging the foundation for his store. It is a foot long, about 6 inches in diameter, and 27 inches in circumference. The shell is the 16th part of an inch in thickness. A hole is drilled in the end of it, and the egg must have been considered of great value by the natives, as it was found deposited at the head of a skeleton, with a number of very large poenamu axes. Mr. Fyfe, we understand, is going to send them home to the British Museum.

Author: BRODIE

Quote: ... which they call the Old Country, the Old Land, the Old Dart, and, in common speech, Home. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1937 
Source: New Zealand From Within
Author: COWIE
Vol / Page: 265
Edition: 
Quote: The word Home on most New Zealanders' lips is no more than a synonym for the United Kingdom; it does not mean `dear old England', or `my beloved birthplace,' or `my real country'; it does not even mean what the United Kingdom means to all Irish Irishmen. It simply means the United Kingdom, and is used without emotion, as a word that has been handed down from father to son, and mother to daughter. It is part of the real New Zealand language, a genuine piece of Antipodean slang. And, like all slang, it has its significance.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1937 
Source: Dictionary of Slang
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 399
Edition: 
Quote: Home. Great Britain and Ireland; esp., an gen., England: Colonial, prob. first in U.S. (by 1912 very ob., says Thornton) in C. 18. In C. 20, mostly Australian and New Zealand. Esp. as as at h., go h. A coll. usage bordering on-indeed, by the O.E.D. considered as-S.E. -4. (home.) A dug-out in the front trench: New Zealand soldiers': 1915-18.
Notes:

Notes: 

Home
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:G.B. and Ireland; esp. and gen. England : Colonial, prob first in U.S. (cf Thornton) in 18c. : 20c Aust and NZ esp. go, at home.]  (It is perhaps possible to distinguish among the earliest recorded uses, a specific reference to England, rather than other parts of the British Isles, or to the British Isles themselves. This would be expected, as most early Company settlers were English born. My evidence suggests that 1840-1860 usage was mainly by settlers in Canterbury, Nelson, and Wellington. There seems no early evidence of its use in Otago.) By the first settlers, and the early generations of colonially born, England; the British Isles; the Old Country; the mother country; one's home country. A. Referring to the homeland left. 1. a. Chiefly `England'. (i) Initial cap. [?more freq. proportionally after WW1]. 
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Date: 4/1/1929 
Source: Na To Hoa Aroha
Author: 
Vol / Page: 1/163
Edition: 1986
Quote: When I presumed to take on the cloak you [Buck] dropped ... and in the borrowed mantle essayed to climb Hikurangi and so catch ... views of the local conflict I was amazed that so much progress had been made in winning the regard ... of the `pakeha'. The generation for which the New Zealand Herald catered in leading articles had almost passed away. Your lectures throughout New Zealand had set the best minds among the pakeha at work. With that generation also had largely passed the pakeha who was wedded to the idea of England being `Home'. The native born New Zealand pakeha is looking nearer to his native heath for objects of study, literary effort and missionary care. 
Notes: (Ngata)

Date: 0/0/1934 
Source: Spur of Morning
Author: MULGAN
Vol / Page: 18
Edition: 
Quote:  `I hope to go Home some day' You mean England, I suppose. `Yes, of course,' replied Philip. He really meant the British Isles with England predominant. ... I don't think of England as Home. ... If there's any `Home' for me in that sense, it's Ireland. But this country is our real home. ... In thinking of England as `Home', Philip was typical of his countrymen. Nearly everyone spoke of `Home' - as naturally as, unknowingly, they sprinkled their speech with current phrases from Shakespeare. 
Notes:

Home Guard
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:Home Defence Force, WWII
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/10/2003 
Source: NZ Memories
Author: 
Vol / Page: No. 44/28
Edition: 
Quote: The Home Guard has atrtracted little attention from historians... There was nothing glamorous about the Home Guard... It was nearly a year after war was declared that the War Cabinet finally laid plans for the formation of a volunteer Home Guard, to comprise men who were too old or to young to serve overseas, or who were being kept at home in essential occupations... The urgency and seriousness of the war eventually forced Home Guard units to be set up in almost every settlement and town in the country... The Home Guard in New Zealand eventually numbered 12,000 in its ranks.

Date: 0/0/1999 
Source: NZ Parliamentary Debates
Author: 
Vol / Page: 575 : 17550
Edition: 
Quote: I move, <i>That the House take note of the report of the Justice and Law Reform Committee on the Crimes (Home Invasion) Amendment Bill</i>... Home invasion is not an everyday offence.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1999 
Source: NZ Statutes
Author: 
Vol / Page: 262
Edition: 
Quote: The definition of home invasion.. is intended	to cover all situations where an offender commits an offence in the process of entering, while inside, and while leaving, places where people live. In the bill as introduced, a home invasion must occur in a "dwellinghouse"... The definition of "dwellinghouse" is.. .intended to encompass the variety of places in which people can live, including caravans, mobile homes and other structures. It focuses on the use to which a building is put, and is therefore not intended to include buildings or parts of buildings that have some other primary purpose, such as a commercial buildings or hospitals... 17A.. ‘Dwellinghouse' means (a) a building or other structure, or part of a building or other structure, that is used by the occupant principally as a residence; or (b) A mobile home, caravan, or houseboat, that is used by the occupant principally as a residence; "Home invasion", when used in the expression ‘the offence involved home invasion'.. means that the person who committed the offence did so... (a) While breaking and entering, or otherwise unlawfully entering, an occupied dwellinghouse; or (b) While in an occupied dwellinghouse, after having broken and entered, or otherwise unlawfully entered, the dwellinghouse; or (c) While breaking out of an occupied dwellinghouse; or (d) While otherwise unlawfully in an occupied dwellinghouse
Notes: Report from the Justice & Law Committee

home separation
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the skimming or separating of cream from milk at the farm where the milk has been produced (rather than being sent as whole milk to a skimming station or dairy factory). 
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 15/6/1910 
Source: NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author: 
Vol / Page: 34
Edition: 
Quote: By 'home separation' is meant the skimming of milk by small cream-separators on the farm and supplying the cream to butter-factories .. the butter generally made at 'home separation' factories is of a distinctly lower grade than the butter made from the cream at factories and skimming-stations where the whole milk is delivered.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1937 
Source: History of the NZ Dairy Industry
Author: PHILPOTT
Vol / Page: 296
Edition: 
Quote: Although home separation has been a most important factor in the working of the butter side of our dairy industry, and today over 95 per cent of our butter is made from cream separated on the farms, the system did not come into practice without strong opposition. Home-separation developed in the first instance on farms remote from a factory or skimming-station ...

Edition: 
Quote: The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. In this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.'
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1947 
Source: Early Runholding in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Vol / Page: 115
Edition: 
Quote: It is usually understood that in the early days the word `station' denoted the owner's house and its immediate buildings, while `run' meant the whole property. Strange to say, I only noted the word `station' twice, and each time with a diverse meaning. On July 21, 1865, the diary says: `Sold 17 head of cattle - remaining on station 15 head.' Then on September 11, 1865, we read: `Wilkinson returned to the Home Station.' The first of these entries means the whole run - the second the homestead or main buildings.
Notes: -->1947 Beattie Early Runholding 115 quoting 1856 July 21 Puketoi Station Diary

Date: 0/0/1971 
Source: Wakatip
Author: GRIFFITHS KING
Vol / Page: 73
Edition: 
Quote: The Rees family barely had time to get settled again at their home station before the quiet pastoral barony ... was invaded by a noisy and often drunken avalanche of gold-seekers.

Edition: 
Quote: Review NZPOD Town house is in, and uneasily acceptable as a `residence in town esp. of person with house in the country' although `in the country' could be better phrased; but `house in (esp. terraced) group in town' is not apt, and increasingly the style for this type of dwelling is townhouse. That is, `My town house is a townhouse', correctly distinguishes, on the page, and will be distinguished in speech; tow stresses for the one, and one stress (TOWNhouse) for the other. There is as well a question of nuance to be noticed. A townhouse is emphatically upmarket from a home unit. 
Notes: Smithyman

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1947 
Source: Early Runholding in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Vol / Page: 11
Edition: 
Quote: The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. In this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.'
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1853 
Source: Auckland
Author: SWAINSON
Vol / Page: 38
Edition: 
Quote: Surrounded by these ornamental woods, ... are here and there clear open spots of ground ... choice sites for homestead, park or garden.

Notes: 

Date: 28/10/1933 
Source: Press, The
Author: 
Vol / Page: 17
Edition: 
Quote: Homestead. In the old days the owner's residence, but only if it was some distance from the rest of the station buildings (see big house). when the Goverment began cutting up the runs in the 'nineties, they or their surveyors adopted the word to signify what had been formerly called the station, and the new settlers followed them, so that the new sense of the word is now widely used. Butler and Sir F. Weld also use it in the modern sense, but in writing for Englishmen. (C.R.)
Notes: Acland Glossary

Homestead Act
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:an early Land Grant law where permanent dwellings had to be erected within twelve months of land occupancy.

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1892 
Source: NZ Official Handbook
Author: 
Vol / Page: 284
Edition: 
Quote: HOMESTEAD SYSTEM. [heading] Under this system the settler makes no payment for the land, the only cost to him being the expenses of survey. On the fulfilment of conditions, which are five years' residence, the erection of a house, and the cultivation of one-third of the selection if open land, and one-fifth if bush-land, the Crown grant is issued.

homeward bounder
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1962 
Source: West Coast Gold Rushes
Author: MAY
Vol / Page: 244
Edition: 1967
Quote: It was a matter of nice judgement. The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: `tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; a `wages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a `riser' was a rich claim; and a `piler' or `homeward bounder' the richest of all. Probably most of the `pilers' were beach-claims, where the leads were shallow and rich, the outlay small and provisions cheap because of easy access.  <i>Ibid.</i> 275 The richest claim was always a `homeward-bounder'. A Nelson digger recalled how at work his mates talked of `trips to Europe, going back for a week, and astonishing the Natives generally'. <I>Ibid.</I> 329 J. F. Byrne & Co. showed off their wares by the light of six kerosene chandeliers and advertised, THE REAL HOMEWARD BOUNDER!/An ounce to the Dish can be Saved/ BY BUYING YOUR/CLOTHING AND BOOTS AT THE CORINTHIAN HALL/ NEW RUSH NEW RUSH /Peg out your claims at the Corinthian Hall If you want to strike a good lead/Dead on the gutter/ BUY YOUR CLOTHING AND BOOTS AN THE CORINTHIAN HALL/ 
Notes:

honeysuckle
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:

Date: 0/0/1917 
Source: Descriptive Catalogue
Author: DUNCAN & DAVIES
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: (And) <I>Knightia excelsa</I> native honey-suckle
Notes: 

honeysuckle
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:Native and introduced spp.; 1. any of various climbing shrubs with small, fragrant, trumpet-shaped, yellow or pink flowers; 2. a) any of various similar but unrelated plants, such asbanksia; b) in New Zealand;  rewarewa. 1. excelsa (Morris: applied in Austr. to Banksias, the `Bottle-brushes' to which the NZ plant is related.) rewa-rewa, bucket-of-water-tree
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1945 
Source: Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author: 
Vol / Page: 54/97
Edition: 
Quote: As each arrives, she goes through the bus, shaking hands and hongi-ing everyone. There is a set patttern for the hongi - clasp hands, briefly press together the tips of the noses, make a wailing sound, press noses briefly for a second time ... Close relatives hongi for a longer period than the formal brief nose-press. 
Notes: (Beaglehole)

Date: 0/0/1946

Date: 0/11/1793 
Source: Journal
Author: KING
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote:  The old Chief who appeared to be about seventy years of age, had not a visible feature, the whole of his face being covered with spiral lines; on his coming on board he embraced Tooke with great affection; after which Tooke introduced me to him, and after the ceremony of Ehonge (i.e., joining noses) he took off his how, how, [sic] or mantle, and put it on my shoulders; ... 
Notes: 1793 Nov King's Journal in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/547

Date: 19/11/1793 
Source: Letter
Author: KING
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: Tookee then introduced him to me, and after the ceremony of etrouge (joining noses) he took off his ha-a-how ... and put it on my shoulders. In return, I made him a present of a ha-a-how made of green baize decorated with broad arrows. 
Notes: 1793 Nov 19 Lieut.-Gov. King to Henry Dundas in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/171-172

Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a Maori. Usu. in pl. (the Hongis); prob. from Hongi Hika, name of an early Maori chief well known from school history books; poss. chiefly a SI term, as unlike Hori, it is not used by Maoris among themselves. 
Origin:Maori

"Fundamentally, " Shaw points out, "there's no reason for a customer to incur an honour fee. An overdraft facility costs you less a year [$28] than two honour fees."

hoodat
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:exclamation
Sense Number:
Definition:who say hoodat, a catchphrase popular among students etc. in 1950's and early 60's, said especially as a welcome to a newcomer to a group, or outsider. Often a meaningless saying. (from who dat say who dat?, from the coloured joke about Rastus / Hori / Jacky etc, who comes home suddenly when a friend is in bed with his wife. The adulterer gets out of his bed, and tries to creep out under cover of darkness. Rastus hears him,in the dark, and says `Hoo dat?' being answered by silence, until the adulterer bumps into him in the dark, and says himself `Hoo dat?' Rastus immediately says `Hoo dat who say hoo dat'. The story has many variants, and is variously placed in stage Black, Maori or Aboriginal contexts.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

hoof cultivation
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:the use of grazing stock to aerate soil or to cultivate pasture. 
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 1/9/1937 
Source: NZ Farmer
Author: 
Vol / Page: 11
Edition: 
Quote: I mentioned previously the hoof cultivation by sheep.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1928 
Source: Tour in Australia and NZ
Author: STAPLEDON
Vol / Page: 55
Edition: 
Quote: A Tour in Australia and New Zealand 55 Concentration of grazing carries with it other important effects - the benefits of what Bruce Levy has so appropriately termed 'hoof cultivation.' In New Zealand the soil dries so rapidly after rain that the 'hoof' seldom does harm and most frequently only does good - provided of course that a period of rest follows a period of excessive 'cultivation.' The combined application of 'hoof cultivation' and judicious feeding out is a method definitely employed for grass land improvement in New Zealand.
Notes:

hook
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a gumfields tool
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1900 
Source: NZ Illustrated Magazine
Author: 
Vol / Page: 3/208
Edition: 
Quote: The tools used by the digger are the spade, the spear and the hook. ... The hook is used for raising the gum from the deeper and wetter swamps. It is a rod of iron perhaps twelve feet long,looped at one end for a handle, and with the last three feet of the other turned off at right angles  and given its own peculiar shape. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1972 
Source: Gumdiggers, The
Author: REED
Vol / Page: 50
Edition: 
Quote: The hook was used for drawing up nuggets of gum from the depths of swamps, after location by the spear. The hook consisted of a galvanised pipe an inch or so in diameter, equipped at one end with a spade handle, and at the other end with a steel `toe,' about an inch and a half in length, welded to the pipe, and forming the `hook'. It is said that expert diggers could bring up with ease gum of various sizes from great depths. 
Notes:

hook on
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:verb
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/1920 
Source: Stories
Author: MANSFIELD
Vol / Page: 193
Edition: (1984 Alpers)
Quote: `Come for a walk round the esplanade, Matilda. I can't stand this any longer.'  `Right-o. I'll put on my ulster. Isn't it an awful day!' Bogey's ulster is just like hers. Hooking the collar she looks at herself in the glass. ... Good-bye, dears; we shall be back soon. `This is better, isn't it?'  [194] `Hook on,' says Bogey.  They cannot walk fast enough. Their heads bent, their legs just touching, they stride like one eager person through the town, ...

Source: Dictionary of Slang Addenda
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 1078
Edition: 
Quote: Hook one's bait (or mutton). To depart; to decamp, make off: New Zealand and Australian: C. 20. Baker. Elaboration of Hook it. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1966 
Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Vol / Page: 177
Edition: 
Quote: Some expressions that have been claimed for New Zealand are at the rate of knots `very fast', hook your mutton `clear out', have the wood on `have an advantage over' and the oaths Blimey Charlie and (By) Christchurch (obviously a neat save suggested by the place name).

Edition: 
Quote:  hook your mutton clear out, similar to `slinging your hook'; eg `Let's hook our mutton, there's no welcome here, fellas.'

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1980 
Source: Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author: LELAND
Vol / Page: 52
Edition: 
Quote: A hooley is a WILD PARTY. In NZ felt to be Irish, (and perhaps associated with hooligan)  but probably a development of OED hoolee (sb) [Hindi holi] E Indies. The great festival or carnival of the Hindoos, held at the approach of the vernal equinox, in honour of Krishna and the Gopis milkmaids < 1687.1800 the hooly, or saturnalia of India, when liberty of speech and action towards superiors are allowed ... 1825. During all the time of Hoolee, drunkenness is common among the Hindoos.  
Notes: 

Date: 7/10/1988 
Source: Contact (Wgtn)
Author: 
Vol / Page: 4
Edition: 
Quote: The bloke that bought the last ie at Saturday's hooley was quite dewy eyed about it next morning .

Quote: <I>Bread and Water</I> is an interesting piece of social history with an intriguing footnote. Apparently the word "hoon" was prison slang for a conscientious objector who had ethical, but not religious, convictions.
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/2001 
Source: Curious Questions
Author: CRYER
Vol / Page: 102
Edition: 
Quote: Before the second World War a hoon was a loutish exhibitionist... [After the war] the word remained in use, but reverted to its earlier sense. A few grammatical extensions also exist: hoonish, hoonism, hooning, hoondom, hoon around, hoon it up, a bit of a hoon, hoon-chaser (traffic police) and hoon-bin(place where drunken football hoons are put to cool off).

hoon
Homonym Number: 
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:a humanitarian, ethical or political objector to military service; a person whose objection to military service is based on other than religious convictions; a political or humanitarian objector 1941-5. ACB: ca1941-45 A.C. Barrington; J. McCreary; a non-religious objector 
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations 
Date: 0/0/2004 
Source: Question of Faith, A
Author: GRANT
Vol / Page: 53
Edition: 
Quote: The third group were non-religious objectors (known as 'hoons'in camp) who were a diverse group, often individualists, who opposed war for a variety of ethical and humanitarian reasons... Christian pacifists and some 'hoons' mixed well and learned from each other. 'Hoon' George Gunn recalled that the Methodists "simply glowed with humanity."
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/2000 
Source: Bread and Water
Author: FOOTE
Vol / Page: 14
Edition: 
Quote: However, a number of Christian pacificsts and some 'hoons', - humanitarian/ethical/political objectors - felt this argument was a cop out. <i>Ibid.</i> 62 The majority of the Christian pacifists in detention were Methodists. Hoon George Gunn wrote, "they simply glowed with humanity."
Notes: Used in WWII period

Source: Curious Questions
Author: CRYER
Vol / Page: 102
Edition: 
Quote: During the war the same word [sc. hoon]underwent a complete reversal of meaning. Poeple who were conscientious objectors on other than religious grounds were known to the military as hoons...
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1953 
Source: Till Human Voices Wake Us
Author: HAM,ILTON
Vol / Page: 154
Edition: 
Quote: I hadn't been in detention long when I heard his name mentioned ...He hadn't gone to jail with the first group ...They reckoned he'd stuck to his religion all through and the Hoons [(fn) non - religious groups] gave me the impression that he took his religion seriously ... you couldn't take much notice of the Hoons of course, not about a thing like that. Most of them just lumped thereligoes together ... . <i>Ibid.</i>  164 There was a sort of line drawn in the [detention] campsbetwen the Hoons and the religoes. ... The religoes were divided again into God knows how many sects and amongst the hoons were absolute pacifists, pacifists, Communists, Anarchists, humanists, and plain dodgers. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1982 
Source: Love and War
Author: SANDYS
Vol / Page: 244
Edition: 
Quote: `I'm lucky to be here [in a detention camp for conscientious objectors]. Reckon they must have got me mixed up with the Hoons. I'd be much worse off in a regular gaol.' `Are all the men here pacifists?' ... / `But you'd have a job getting anything like a consensus out of the lot we've got here. Some are war resisters- ... Then there are the Christians. ... They're still trying to work out how the hell they landed up [here] ... The majority are Hoons - military defaulters. Against war for reasons of sanity and humanity, not out of religious conviction.

Vol / Page: 13

Quote: The best-known primer for this kind of activity, and indeed an integral part of the hoon-ethos itself, is the drinking game. Designed to take the monotony out of rapid, heavy drinking, the drinking game perhaps found its purest expression in the version entitled Next. Down a drink as fast as possible (commonly known as `sculling'), turn to the bloke on your left and say `Next', whereupon he does the same ... very efficient.

Date: 12/1/1896 
Source: Truth (Sydney)
Author: 
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: `There are several specimens of bush slang transplanted from the Maori language. `Hoot' is a very frequent synonym for money or wage. I have heard a shearer at the Pastoralist Union office in Sydney when he sought to ascertain the scale of remuneration, enquire of the gilt-edged clerk behind the barrier, `What's the hoot, mate?' The Maori equivalent for money is utu, pronounced by the Ngapuhi and other northern tribes with the last syllable clipped, and the word is very largely used by the kauri-gum diggers and station hands in the North Island. The original  meaning of first settled in New Zealand, they found that the savage inhabitants had no conception of any recompense except the grim recompense of blood. Under Christianizing influences the natives were induced to forego the blood-revenge for injuries, on receiving asolatium  in goods or land, and so utu came to have the double meaning of revenge and recompense, and eventually became recognized as the Maori word for money.' 
Notes:

Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1990 
Source: Personal Communication
Author: H W ORSMAN
Vol / Page: 
Edition: 
Quote: A. Maori contexts. Orig. a European rendering of the Maori noun utu, return (for anything ); satisfaction, ransom, reward,  price, reply' (Williams); not to be used confused with uto `revenge', a confusion evident in many of the explanations of the meaning of utu). The word widely used was in all the above senses by Europeans who had dealings with Maoris, from the general `return for work, injury, etc.' to the concrete `money' It is often found constructed with the definite article `the utu, hutu' etc. translating  the original Maori indefinite article, or adjective `some' he utu `an utu, some utu'. (Occas. constr with indef. article, see 1834). In later European usage the definite article was dropped to conform to English idiom eg' `give me the hoot' becomes `give me (some) hoot' The following is perhaps a `transitional' use 1828 C Davis journal Colenso Papers 3/18) `Another chief had been killed as a utu or payment'. (Is this [ei utu] reflecting Maori [(h)e utu], as well as English  a for an?). The phonology, resulting in the English  hoot, parallels that of toot from  tutu, with the final unvoiced [u] not being heard by English ears. The initial [h] derives perhaps from a syncopation of [he utu]; but more prob. from the var. or error noted on p. 4 of 1842:  Maunsell Grammar of the New Zealand Language (4th ed) 1894: `In  pronouncing u, the speaker will have to guard against the error of those who prefix the aspirate when no aspirate is admissable. According to the u, utu, etc., are pronounced as if spelt hu, hutu.'. 
Notes: 

Date: 0/0/1964 
Source: Book of New Zealand, A (J.C. Reid)
Author: 
Vol / Page: 285
